chunks.original_text: 精诚 精者，明也。 诚者，信也。 诚者天之性也，精者人之明也。 诚以志之，明以辩之。 非天下至诚，安能尽人物之性，合天地之德？ 故曰不精不诚，不能动人，斯之谓也。 老子曰：天致其高，地致其厚，日月照，列星朗，阴阳和，非有为焉。 无为所致，非有欲也。 正其道而物自然，言君正其身，民化如神，不言之教，莫之与邻也。 阴阳四时，非生万物也，雨露时降，非养草木也，神明接，阴阳和，万物生矣。 天地和泰，神明交降，非有心也。 四时不得，不顺万物，不得不生。 夫道者藏精於内，栖神於心，静漠恬啖，悦穆胸中，廓然无形，寂然无声。 言圣人怀天心，施德养道，内韫精神，外无人物，都无兆#1眹，岂有形声。 官府若无事，朝廷若无人，无苛政，无佞人。 无隐士，无逸民，朝廷皆忠烈岩野无遗贤，无劳役，无冤刑，使民以时，用法无滥。 天下莫不仰上之德，象主之旨，绝国殊俗，莫不重译而至，君有其道，人赖其德，远被八表，旁流殊俗。 非家至而人见之也，推其诚心，施之天下而已。 言致重译怀殊俗，非人君一一自诣其家，是诚心内发，远人自至也。 故赏善罚暴者，正令也，其所以能行者，精诚也。 令虽明不能独行，必待精诚，精明也，诚信也，非明与信，莫能赏善伐恶。 故总道以被民而民弗从者，精诚弗至也。 如禹伐有苗，不伏然后退，舞干羽而有苗格，精诚至也。 老子曰：天设日明，列星辰，张四时，调阴阳，日以暴之，夜以息之，风以乾之，雨露以濡之。 其生物也，莫见其所养而万物长； 其杀物也，莫见其所丧而万物亡，此谓神明。 天道潜运，难可明言。 物之生时也，物之死时也，生者，至时不得不生，死者，至时不得不死。 即生者合生，死者合死。 故生者不谢於天，死者不怨於道，自然而已。 所谓神明。 是故圣人象之，其起福也，不见其所以而福起； 其除祸也，不见其所由而祸除。 稽之不得，察之不虚。 上言天法道，此言圣人法天。 天之有生杀，由君之有赏罚。 起福谓用贤，除祸谓去恶。 恶者不得不诛，贤者不得不进。 是贤者自进而非我进，暴者自诛而非我诛。 故福非我起，祸非我生，莫知所由，不见其形。 日计不足，岁计有余。 圣人不谋细，日用似不足，岁计乃有余也。 寂然无声，一言而大动天下，是以天心动化者也。 夫圣人其静也，天下无声。 其动也，万物归之。 故高宗三年不言，言乃谨。 有诸也。 故精诚内形气，动於天，景星见，黄龙下，凤凰至，醴泉出，嘉谷生，河不满溢，海不波涌； 圣人体道，育物，唯德动天。 内发於心，上应於天，故龙凤翔集，河海清澄，非无清诚，曷能至此？ 逆天暴物，即日月薄蚀，五星失行，四时相乘，昼冥宵光，山崩川涸，冬雷夏霜，天之与人有以相通。 上明天之应以喜祥，此明逆之致咎灾。 故知祸福无门，唯人所召，故天人相通，气类相感，必不差也。 故国之姐亡也，天文变，世俗乱，虹蜺见，万物有以相连，精气有以相薄。 悖气胜，灾害以变物，应之以凶，是故圣人审知一身，通乎万类，兢兢业业不敢荒，宁将上顺天心以安黔首，不敢悔慢也。 故神明之事，不可以智巧为也，不可以强力致也。 夫神明正直，岂容巧伪？
chunks.translated_text:
Purity and sincerity—purity is clarity, sincerity is trust. Sincerity is heaven’s nature; purity is man’s clarity. Sincerity is upheld by the will, clarity is distinguished by discernment. Without the utmost sincerity under heaven, how could one fully realize the natures of all beings and unite with heaven and earth’s virtue? Thus it is said: without purity and sincerity, one cannot move others—this is what it means.

Laozi said: Heaven attains its height, earth attains its depth; the sun shines, the stars gleam; yin and yang harmonize—not through deliberate action. What is achieved by non-action arises not from desire. Align with the Dao, and things naturally follow. When the ruler rectifies himself, the people are transformed as if by spirit; the teaching of no words has no equal.

The four seasons and yin-yang do not generate the myriad things; timely rain and dew do not nourish grasses and trees. Yet when spirit and clarity connect, when yin and yang harmonize, the myriad things are born. When heaven and earth are harmonious and at peace, when spirit and clarity intermingle and descend—this is not a matter of intention. The four seasons cannot but follow their course, and the myriad things cannot but be born.

The Dao conceals purity within, harbors spirit in the heart, abides in stillness and tranquility, delights in harmony within the breast. Vast and formless, silent and soundless—this is how the sage embraces heaven’s heart, bestows virtue, and nurtures the Dao. Inwardly, spirit is stored; outwardly, no trace of beings appears. Without omen or sign, how could there be form or sound?

Government offices are as if empty of affairs; the court is as if empty of people. There are no harsh policies, no flatterers, no recluses, no idle folk. The court is filled with loyal and steadfast men, the wilderness holds no hidden worthies. There are no corvée labors, no unjust punishments; the people are employed in season, laws are applied without excess.

Under heaven, none do not look up to the ruler’s virtue, emulate the sovereign’s intent. Even distant lands and foreign customs, none do not come through repeated translation. The ruler possesses the Dao, and the people rely on his virtue. His influence extends to the eight directions, flowing even to alien customs. It is not that he visits every household in person—he merely extends his sincere heart to all under heaven. Thus, though distant peoples and foreign customs come to submit, it is not that the ruler visits each home himself; rather, his sincere heart issues forth, and distant peoples naturally arrive.

Thus, rewarding the good and punishing the violent is proper governance, but what enables it to be carried out is purity and sincerity. Though commands may be clear, they cannot act alone—they must await purity and sincerity. Purity is clarity; sincerity is trust. Without clarity and trust, none can reward the good and punish the evil.

Therefore, when the Dao is universally applied yet the people do not follow, it is because purity and sincerity have not reached them. As when Yu attacked the Miao, they did not submit, and he withdrew—only when he danced with shields and feathers did the Miao come to terms. This was the power of purity and sincerity.

Laozi said: Heaven establishes the sun’s brightness, arrays the stars, extends the four seasons, regulates yin and yang. By day it exposes things, by night it lets them rest; the wind dries them, rain and dew moisten them. In generating things, none see how they are nourished, yet the myriad things grow. In destroying things, none see how they perish, yet the myriad things die—this is called spirit and clarity. The Dao of heaven operates in hiddenness; it is difficult to express in words.

When things are born, it is their time, and they cannot but be born. When things die, it is their time, and they cannot but die. Thus, the living align with life, the dead align with death. Therefore, the living do not thank heaven, the dead do not resent the Dao—it is simply natural. This is what is meant by spirit and clarity.

Thus, the sage emulates this. When fortune arises, none see how it begins; when misfortune is removed, none see its cause. It cannot be traced, yet it is not false. Above, it was said that heaven follows the Dao; here, it is said that the sage follows heaven. Heaven’s life and death correspond to the ruler’s rewards and punishments. "Fortune arising" refers to employing the worthy; "misfortune removed" refers to eliminating the evil. The evil cannot but be punished; the worthy cannot but be advanced. Thus, the worthy advance of themselves, not because I advance them; the violent are punished of themselves, not because I punish them. Therefore, fortune does not arise from me, nor does misfortune originate from me. None know its source; none see its form.

Daily reckoning seems insufficient, but yearly reckoning shows surplus. The sage does not scheme over trifles; daily use may seem inadequate, but yearly accounting shows abundance. Silent and soundless, a single word stirs all under heaven—this is how heaven’s heart moves and transforms.

When the sage is still, all under heaven is silent. When he moves, the myriad things return to him. Thus, Gaozong did not speak for three years, yet when he spoke, his words were revered. Such was the case.

Thus, purity and sincerity take form within, moving heaven. Auspicious stars appear, yellow dragons descend, phoenixes arrive, sweet springs flow, fine grains grow. Rivers do not overflow, seas do not surge—this is how the sage embodies the Dao and nurtures beings. Only virtue moves heaven. Issuing from the heart, it responds above to heaven. Thus, dragons and phoenixes soar and gather; rivers and seas become clear and still. Without pure sincerity, how could this be achieved?

To defy heaven and harm beings brings solar and lunar eclipses, wandering stars, seasons out of joint, days darkened and nights lit, mountains collapsing and rivers drying, winter thunder and summer frost. Heaven and man communicate thus. Above, it was shown how heaven responds with auspicious omens; here, it is shown how defiance brings calamity and disaster.

Thus, know that misfortune and fortune have no fixed gate—they are summoned by man. Heaven and man communicate; qi and kindred types resonate—this cannot be mistaken. Therefore, when a state is about to perish, celestial signs change, customs grow chaotic, rainbows appear. All things are interconnected; pure qi presses upon one another. When perverse qi prevails, calamities transform beings, responding with misfortune.

Thus, the sage examines his own person and understands the myriad kinds. Diligent and cautious, he dares not be negligent. He would rather align above with heaven’s heart to pacify the black-haired people than dare to be remiss. Therefore, matters of spirit and clarity cannot be achieved by cleverness or force. Spirit and clarity are upright—how could they tolerate deceit and falsity?

chunks.original_text: 非诚心莫应，况强力能通哉。 故大人与天地合德，与日月合明，与鬼神合灵，与四时合信。 唯大圣为能体至道，合天心，故德无不傋，明无不烛，灵不虚应，信不逾时，有能与斯，可谓大哉。 怀天心，抱地气，执冲含和，心气相通，天地交泰，非体冲和，岂至如此？ 不下堂而行四海，其唯神化。 变忌习俗，民化迁善，若出诸己，能以神化者也。 夫圣人不以尊卑易己，不以夷夏易情，故不下堂而殊俗化，不驰神而重译至，德加乎人，若出诸己者。 老子曰：夫人道者全性保真，不亏其身，夫人识道体，合天理，在物无害，於身不亏也。 遭急迫难，精通乎天。 诚至无违。

Only with utmost sincerity can there be response—how could force ever penetrate? Thus, the great person’s virtue merges with heaven and earth, his clarity merges with sun and moon, his numinosity merges with ghosts and spirits, his trustworthiness merges with the four seasons. Only the supreme sage can embody the perfect Dao and align with heaven’s heart; thus, his power leaves nothing unencompassed, his illumination leaves nothing unillumined, his numinosity responds without emptiness, his trustworthiness never transgresses the proper time. One who can attain this may be called great indeed.

He embraces heaven’s heart, holds earth’s qi, grasps the balanced and contains harmony. When heart and qi communicate, heaven and earth unite in peace—how could one who does not embody balance and harmony ever reach such a state? Without descending the hall, he travels the four seas—this is the work of spiritual transformation. Changing taboos and customs, the people are transformed toward goodness as if it arose from themselves—this is the power of spiritual transformation.

The sage does not alter himself for high or low, nor change his feelings for barbarian or Chinese. Thus, without descending the hall, he transforms diverse customs; without extending his spirit, envoys from distant lands arrive. His virtue extends to others as if it arose from themselves.

Laozi said: "For the person who follows the Dao, preserving nature and safeguarding authenticity, nothing harms his person. One who comprehends the Dao’s essence and aligns with heaven’s principle remains unharmed by things and uninjured in himself. When pressed by urgent peril, his essence communicates with heaven. Sincerity reaches its utmost without deviation."

chunks.original_text: 若乃未始出其宗者，何为而不成，死生同域，不可胁凌。 未始出其宗者，是心与道冥，身齐化物，何往不适，何为不成，死生已泯，安可胁凌也？ 又况官天地，府万物，返造化，含至和而已，未尝死者也。 道者，法天象地，含阴吐阳，分布五材，包罗万品，独运陶钧之上，周行造化之表，未尝有生，孰云其死？ 精诚形乎内，而外喻於人心，此不传之道也。 此言内育精诚，外感人物，其可传乎。 圣人在上，怀道而不言，泽及万民，故不言之教芒乎大哉。 君臣乖心，倍谲见乎天，神气相应征矣，此谓不言之辩，不道之道也。 至道无言，玄功不宰。 故君臣相保，诵咏其德，止达于天，幽通于神，不言之辩，不道之道，所能致也。 夫召远者，使无为焉，亲近者，言无事焉，言天之高远，唯无为感之而应，无事亲之，则近也。 唯夜行者能有之，夜行谓勤行，如夜行，未迨所诣，陪行一不息，所以精神内发，上达于天。 故却走马以粪，却者，罢也。 马者，心也。 心如佚马，难可控御。 人皆驰心，远希名利，以荣其身。 我则不然，罢走其心，保将虚静，以粪其身也。 车轨不接於远方之外，是谓坐驰陆沉。 不行而至，谓之坐驰。 隐而不发，谓之陆沉。 夫天道无私就也，无私去也，能者有余，拙者不足，夫天道无私，有德者则就，无德则去。 观夫去彼取此，涉於有私，及乎舍恶亲善，理合自然。 无欲则有余，有欲则不赡也已。 顺之者利，逆之者凶。 唯无私无为，故无利无功。 是故以智为治者，难以持国，已释上经。 唯同乎大和，而持自然应者，为能有之。 唯全大和，自然应之。 老子曰：夫道之与德，若韦之与革，远之即近，近之即疏，稽之不得，察之不虚。 夫韦革为鼓，击之则应，道德资身，用之则行。 声应莫穷，神化无极。 是考之不得，察之不虚也。 是故圣人若镜，不将不迎，应而不藏，万物而不伤，其心若镜，所鉴无遗。 不迎物而求照，必恒照而应物，物无逃像，所遇何伤也？ 其得之也乃失之也，其失之也乃得之也。 有得有失，斯为不实。 无得无失，斯为真一。 故通於大和者，暗若醉而甘卧以游其中，若未始出其宗，是谓大通。 夫抱道含和，忘形遗累，如饮醇酎，甘乐其中，混然而同，可谓大道者也。 此假不用能成其用也。 此谓悟道以无生，如因醉以忘形也。 老子曰：昔黄帝之治天下，调日月之行，治阴阳之气，节四时之度，正律历之数，别男女，明上下，使强不掩弱。 众不暴寡，民保命而不夭，岁时熟而不凶，百官正而无私，上下调而无尤，法令明而不暗，辅佐公而不阿，田者让畔，道不拾遗，市不预贾，故於此时日月星辰不失其行，风雨时节，五谷丰昌，凤凰翔於庭，麒麟游於郊。 此黄帝以道治天下，德化如是。 虙牺氏之王天下也，枕石寝绳，杀秋约冬，负方州，抱员天，阴阳所拥。 沈滞不通者，窍理之逆气戾物，伤民厚积者绝止之。 其民童蒙，不知西东，视瞑瞑，行蹎蹎，侗然自得，莫知其所由浮游，泛然不知所本，自#2养不知所如往。 此明虙牺氏之洽天下也如此。 当此之时，禽兽虫蛇无不怀其爪牙，藏其螫毒，功揆天地。 虽含毒螫之情，而无残害之心，至德所加，故能若此也。
chunks.translated_text:
Should one never depart from their fundamental source, what could they not accomplish? Death and life share the same domain, and none can coerce or oppress them. Never departing from their source means the mind merges with the Dao, the body equalizes with transformations—where could they not go, what could they not achieve? Death and life are already dissolved; how could they be coerced or oppressed?

Moreover, to govern heaven and earth, to encompass the myriad things, to return to the workings of creation, and to contain perfect harmony—this is to have never died. The Dao models itself on heaven and earth, embraces yin and exhales yang, distributes the five agents, and envelops the ten thousand kinds. Alone, it operates above the potter’s wheel of creation, circulating beyond the bounds of transformation—it has never been born, so who could speak of its death?

Sincerity takes form within and outwardly resonates in the hearts of others—this is the untransmitted Dao. This speaks of nurturing sincerity within and externally moving others; can it be transmitted? When the sage resides above, embracing the Dao without speaking, his beneficence extends to the myriad people. Thus, the teaching without words is vast indeed.

When ruler and minister diverge in heart, deceit and treachery manifest in heaven, and the correspondence of spirit and qi is evident—this is called the eloquence of the wordless, the Dao of the unspoken. The supreme Dao is without speech; its mysterious workings do not dominate. Therefore, when ruler and minister preserve one another, chanting and extolling virtue, it reaches heaven above and communicates in secret with the spirits. The eloquence of the wordless, the Dao of the unspoken—these are what they attain.

To summon the distant, let there be non-action; to draw near, let speech be without affairs. The height and remoteness of heaven can only be moved by non-action to respond, and by non-affairs to be made close. Only those who walk in the night can attain this—walking in the night means diligent practice, like traveling at night, not yet reaching the destination, yet accompanying the journey without ceasing. Thus, the spirit is inwardly aroused and ascends to heaven.

Therefore, dismiss the galloping horse to manure the fields—"dismiss" means to cease. The "horse" is the heart. The heart, like a runaway horse, is difficult to control. People all gallop after their hearts, chasing distant fame and profit to glorify themselves. I, however, do not act thus: I cease the galloping of my heart, preserving emptiness and stillness to nourish my person.

When the tracks of chariots do not reach beyond distant lands, this is called "sitting in motion and sinking into obscurity." To arrive without traveling is called "sitting in motion"; to remain hidden without emerging is called "sinking into obscurity." The Way of heaven is impartial in approach and departure; the capable have abundance, the inept fall short. The Way of heaven is impartial: those with virtue it approaches, those without it departs.

Observe how choosing this and abandoning that involves partiality, yet when forsaking evil and embracing good, the principle aligns with nature. Without desire, there is abundance; with desire, there is insufficiency. Following it brings benefit; opposing it brings misfortune. Only through impartiality and non-action is there neither benefit nor merit.

Thus, those who govern with cunning find it difficult to maintain the state—this was already explained in the previous section. Only those who harmonize with the great harmony and uphold natural responsiveness can possess it. Only by preserving the great harmony and naturally responding can one attain it.

Laozi said: The Dao and virtue are like rawhide and leather—distance makes them seem near, closeness makes them seem far. Scrutiny finds nothing, yet investigation is not in vain. Rawhide and leather form a drum: strike it, and it responds. The Dao and virtue sustain the person: employ them, and they function. The resonance is inexhaustible, the spiritual transformation boundless. Thus, examination finds nothing, yet investigation is not in vain.

Therefore, the sage is like a mirror: neither advancing nor retreating, responding without concealing. The myriad things do not harm him; his heart is like a mirror, reflecting all without omission. He does not seek to illuminate by approaching things but constantly reflects and responds to them. No image escapes; what harm could come from encounters?

What is gained is thereby lost; what is lost is thereby gained. Gain and loss reveal insubstantiality; without gain or loss, there is true unity. Thus, one who penetrates the great harmony is dim as if drunk, sweetly reclining and roaming within it—never having departed from their source, this is called great penetration. Embracing the Dao and containing harmony, forgetting form and relinquishing burdens, like drinking fine wine, delighting in its midst, merging indistinguishably—this is the great Dao. This is the use of non-use to accomplish its function. This is awakening to the Dao through non-birth, like forgetting form through drunkenness.

Laozi said: In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor governed the world by harmonizing the movements of the sun and moon, regulating the qi of yin and yang, moderating the measures of the four seasons, rectifying the calculations of pitch pipes and calendars, distinguishing male and female, clarifying superior and inferior, ensuring the strong did not oppress the weak, and the many did not tyrannize the few. The people preserved their lives without premature death; the years were abundant without famine. The hundred officials were upright and impartial; superiors and inferiors were harmonious without blame. Laws and commands were clear and not obscure; assistants were just and not obsequious. Farmers yielded boundaries; roads were free of lost items; markets did not engage in speculative pricing. Thus, at that time, the sun, moon, and stars did not deviate from their courses; wind and rain came in season; the five grains flourished; phoenixes soared in the courtyards, and qilin roamed the outskirts. Such was the Yellow Emperor’s governance of the world through the Dao, and the transformation through virtue.

Fuxi ruled the world resting his head on stone and sleeping on ropes, killing in autumn and executing in winter, bearing the square earth and embracing the round heaven, embraced by yin and yang. Where stagnation and blockage did not flow, the qi of obstructed principles and perverse things that harmed the people and accumulated excessively were cut off. His people were like unlearned children, not knowing east from west, their vision dim, their steps faltering, yet content and self-assured, unaware of their drifting, floating without knowing their origin, nurturing themselves without knowing where to go.

At that time, birds, beasts, insects, and snakes all sheathed their claws and fangs, concealed their stings and poisons. Though they harbored the nature of venom and sting, they had no intent to harm—such was the reach of supreme virtue.

One who comprehends the Dao’s essence and aligns with heaven’s principle remains unharmed by things and uninjured in himself. When pressed by urgent peril, his essence communicates with heaven. chunks.original_text: 至黄帝要缪未详乎太祖之下，然而不章其功，不扬其名，隐真人之道，以从天地之固然，何即道德，上通而智故消灭也。 太祖，黄帝之先也，其人朴，其性野，有功而不德，有名而不扬，故曰隐真人之道，绝浮嚣之智，因自然通於天地也。 老子曰：天不定，日月无所载，地不定，草木无所立，身不宁，是非无所形。 三才不宁，万物失所，若不习志专心，反听内视，则真人不见，真智不生也。 是故有真人而后有真智，其所持者不明，何知吾所谓知之非不知与。 所守不明，何以知道？ 是知者非不知道也。
chunks.translated_text:
At the time of the Yellow Emperor, the essential subtleties remained obscure beneath the Great Ancestor, yet his achievements went uncelebrated, his name unproclaimed. Concealing the Way of the True Person, he followed the inherent constancy of heaven and earth. What, then, of the Dao and its virtue? When the upper reaches are penetrated, cunning and artifice vanish.

The Great Ancestor preceded the Yellow Emperor. His people were unadorned, their nature untamed. Though he accomplished works, he claimed no virtue; though he bore a name, he did not exalt it. Thus it is said: he concealed the Way of the True Person, severed the clamor of superficial wisdom, and accorded with the natural communion of heaven and earth.

Laozi said: If heaven is unsettled, the sun and moon have nothing to bear them; if earth is unsettled, grasses and trees have nowhere to stand; if the self is not at peace, right and wrong take no shape. When the Three Powers are not at peace, the myriad things lose their place. If one does not cultivate single-minded devotion, turning inward to listen and reflect, then the True Person remains unseen, and true wisdom does not arise.

Thus, only with the True Person does true wisdom emerge. If what one holds is not illuminated, how can one know whether what I call knowledge is not ignorance? If what one preserves is not clear, how can one know the Dao?

This is to know that the knower does not fail to know the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 积惠重货，使万民欣欣，人乐其生者，仁也。 举大功，显令名，体君臣，正上下，明亲疏，存危国，继绝世，立无后者，义也。 仁而建物，义以存诚，人无不怀，事无不济，此盖治世王霸之道。 闭九窍，藏志意，弃聪明，反无识，芒然仿佯乎尘垢之外，逍遥乎无事之际，含阴吐阳而与万物同和者，德也。 内冥外顺，藏精育真，无为逍遥，而外尘垢，是故道散而为德，德溢而为仁义，仁义立而道德废矣。 既散纯精，空余糟粕。 老子曰：神越者言华，德荡者行伪，至精芒乎中，而言行观乎外，此不免以身役物也。 内溢至精，外生华藻，心役於事，身宁免害。 精有愁尽而行无穷极，所守不定而外淫於世俗之风。 内守不定则绝境致泥，外驰不息则常苦风波。 是故圣人内修道术，而不外饰仁义，知九窍四肢之宜，而游乎精神之和，此圣人之游也。 圣人内守真旨，外应物宜，故得精神之和，而游乎无穷者也。 老子曰：若夫圣人之游也，即动乎至虚，游心乎大无，驰於方外，行於无门，听於无声，视於无形，不拘於世，不系於俗。 夫动乎至虚，则无所不通。 游乎太无，则无所不有。 何门户之拘制，岂视听之滑昏哉？ 故圣人所以动天下者，真人不过，贤人所以矫世俗者，圣人不观。 夫真圣异迹，功业相县，由祀不得，庖各司其位。 夫人拘於世俗，必形击而神泄，故不免於累。 未有居荣显不役精神，既受其禄，必忧其事也。 使我可拘系者，必其命有在外者矣。 既受羁系，则命不在我也。 老子曰：人主之思，神不驰於胸中，智不出於四域，怀其仁诚之心，甘雨以时，五谷蕃殖，春生、夏长、秋收、冬藏，月省时考，终岁献贡。 夫有道之主，不劳神虑，不炫智能，而远方怀之。 故得上顺天心，下因物宜，万姓奉戴，贡献不绝。 养民以公，威厉不诫#3法省不烦，教化如神，法宽刑缓，囹圄空虚，天下一俗，莫怀奸心，此圣人之恩也。 公而无私，威而不猛，法约刑缓，人从其化，可谓至神。 故万方攸同，殊俗一轨，此圣人恩治天下。 夫上好取而无量，即下贪功而无让，民贫苦而分争生事，力劳而无功，智诈萌生，盗贼滋彰，上下相怨，号令不行。 言上数者，非圣人之所治天下也。 若以此治，即亡无日矣。 夫水浊者鱼噞，政苛者民乱，上多欲即下多诈，上烦扰即下不定，上多求即下交争，不治其本而救之於末，无以异於凿渠而止水，抱薪而救火。 执本以御末，则功简而天下治。 持未以求#4本，则身劳而天下乱。 由决渠水溢，益薪火炽，莫能救也。 圣人事省而治，求寡而赡#5，不施而仁，不言而信，不求而得，不为而成。 怀自然，保至真，抱道推诚，天下从之，如响之应声，影之像形，所修者本也。 至圣之理，在乎简易，则天下所宗，如声应响，影之像形，莫不应也。 老子曰：精神越於外，智虑荡於内者不能治。 形神之所用者远，则所遗者近。 求之非分，恣之无厌，内伤精神，外遗形体。 故不出於户以知天下，不窥於牖以知天道，其出弥远，其知弥少，此言精诚发於内，神气动於天也。 举要会以观天下，故人情可察。 执璇玑以观大运，则天道可明。 诚言发乎中，精气应乎天，所守者近，所明者远，务者多，所知者少也。

Accumulating kindness and valuing wealth, bringing joy to the myriad people so that they delight in life—this is *ren* (benevolence). Achieving great deeds, making one’s illustrious name known, embodying the proper relationship between ruler and minister, rectifying the hierarchy of high and low, clarifying the distinctions of near and far, preserving imperiled states, continuing severed lineages, and establishing heirs where none exist—this is *yi* (righteousness). Through *ren* one establishes things, and through *yi* one preserves sincerity; thus, none fail to cherish it, and no affair goes unaccomplished. This is the Way of kings and hegemons in governing the world.

Closing the nine apertures, concealing one’s will and intentions, relinquishing cleverness and insight, returning to non-discernment, wandering in boundless vagueness beyond the dust and grime, roaming freely in the realm of non-action, inhaling yin and exhaling yang to harmonize with the myriad things—this is *de* (virtue/power). Inwardly obscure yet outwardly compliant, concealing essence to nurture the true, acting without contrivance while remaining untouched by external defilements—thus, the Dao disperses and becomes *de*, and *de* overflows into *ren* and *yi*. Yet once *ren* and *yi* are established, the Dao and *de* are abandoned. What was once pure essence scatters, leaving only dregs.

Laozi said: When the spirit scatters, words become florid; when *de* dissipates, conduct becomes false. When the utmost essence is obscured within, yet words and actions are scrutinized without, one cannot avoid being enslaved by things. When inner essence overflows, external embellishments arise; when the mind is ensnared by affairs, how can the body escape harm? Essence may be exhausted, but actions know no end; if what one preserves is unstable, one becomes externally entangled in worldly customs. If inner preservation is unsteady, one reaches a dead end and sinks into mire; if external pursuits never cease, one is perpetually tormented by storms and waves. Therefore, the sage cultivates the arts of the Dao within and does not outwardly adorn himself with *ren* and *yi*. He understands the proper use of the nine apertures and four limbs, yet roams in the harmony of spirit—this is the sage’s wandering.

The sage inwardly guards the true essence while outwardly responding to things as they are; thus, he attains the harmony of spirit and roams in the boundless. Laozi said: As for the sage’s wandering, he moves in perfect emptiness, his mind roams in the great void, gallops beyond the four directions, acts without gateways, listens without sound, and sees without form. Unconstrained by the world, unbound by custom—moving in perfect emptiness, there is nothing he does not penetrate; roaming in the great void, there is nothing he does not possess. What gate or door could confine him? How could sight or hearing be clouded? Thus, what the sage employs to move the world is not what the True Person surpasses, and what the worthy use to correct世俗 is not what the sage observes. The traces of the True and the sagely differ, their achievements and undertakings diverge—like ancestral sacrifices and kitchen duties, each attends to their proper place.

Those bound by世俗 must manifest their form and dissipate their spirit, and thus cannot escape entanglement. None who dwell in glory and prominence avoid enslavement of the spirit; having received their emoluments, they must also bear their burdens. If I can be fettered, it is because my fate lies beyond myself. Once shackled, my fate is no longer mine.

Laozi said: When the ruler’s thoughts do not scatter in his breast, nor his wisdom extend beyond the four domains; when he cherishes a heart of benevolence and sincerity, sweet rains fall in season, the five grains flourish, spring brings growth, summer brings maturity, autumn brings harvest, winter brings storage, and monthly reviews and seasonal assessments culminate in annual tribute—such is the ruler with the Dao. He does not exhaust his spirit in deliberation nor flaunt his wisdom and ability, yet distant lands are drawn to him. Thus, he aligns above with the heart of heaven and below with the proper order of things, and the myriad people offer their allegiance, their tribute unceasing. He nurtures the people with impartiality, his majesty is awe-inspiring yet not harsh, his laws are few and punishments lenient. Transformation occurs as if by spirit, laws are broad and penalties mild, prisons stand empty, the world shares a single custom, and none harbor treacherous hearts—this is the sage’s grace.

Impartial yet not selfish, majestic yet not fierce, laws concise and punishments mild, people follow his transformation—this may be called the utmost spirit. Thus, all directions are united, diverse customs follow a single path—this is the sage’s grace in governing the world. If those above covet without measure, those below will vie for merit without restraint; the people grow impoverished and distressed, disputes arise, toil yields no fruit, cunning and deceit sprout, and bandits and thieves proliferate. Above and below resent one another, decrees go unheeded. The aforementioned conditions are not how the sage governs the world. To rule thus is to court ruin without delay.

When water is turbid, fish gasp; when governance is harsh, the people rebel. When those above are full of desires, those below are full of deceit; when those above are restless, those below are unsettled; when those above make many demands, those below contend with one another. To neglect the root and seek remedy at the branches is no different from digging a channel to stop water or carrying firewood to extinguish a fire. Grasping the root to govern the branches yields effortless success and a well-ordered world; clinging to the branches to seek the root brings labor to the self and chaos to the world—like trying to stop overflowing water by digging channels or quell a raging fire by adding fuel, it cannot be saved.

The sage’s affairs are few yet well-ordered, his demands are few yet sufficient. Without acting, he is benevolent; without speaking, he is trusted; without seeking, he obtains; without striving, he accomplishes. Embracing the natural, preserving the utmost true, holding to the Dao and extending sincerity, the world follows him as echo follows sound, as shadow follows form—what he cultivates is the root. The principle of the utmost sage lies in simplicity and ease, and thus the world reveres him, responding like echo to sound, like shadow to form—none fail to answer.

Laozi said: When the spirit scatters outward and wisdom and deliberation dissipate within, one cannot govern. When the uses of form and spirit extend too far, what is neglected lies close at hand. Pursuing what is not one’s portion and indulging without restraint injures the spirit within and abandons the body without. Thus, one who does not step beyond the door yet knows the world, who does not peer through the window yet knows the Way of heaven— the farther he ventures, the less he knows. This speaks of sincerity issuing from within and spirit and qi moving heaven.

Grasping the essentials to observe the world, the sentiments of people can be discerned. Holding the jade pivot to observe the great movements, the Way of heaven can be illuminated. When sincere words issue from within, essence and qi respond to heaven. What one guards is near, yet what one illuminates is distant; the more one busies oneself, the less one knows.

chunks.original_text: 老子曰：冬日之阳，夏日之阴，物归之而莫之使极，自然至精之感，弗召自来，不去而往，窈窈冥冥，不知所为者而功自成。 冬日之阳，寒者附之。 夏日之阴，炎者麻之。 彼圣人以治天下，阴阳无情，圣人无情，为物自怀，人自归。 故来非所召，往未尝遣也。 待目而照见，待言而使命，其於治难矣。 皋陶喑而为大理，天下无虐刑，何贵乎言者也。 师旷瞽而为太宰，晋国无乱政，何贵乎见者也。 不言之令，不视之见，圣人所以为师也。 夫不言而化，下无虐刑，岂烦於言哉？ 不视而治，晋国无乱，政何假乎见哉？ 是以不待目而视，不须言而令，故圣人所以为师也。 民之化上，不从其言，从其所行，上古行而不言，末世言而不行。 故人君好勇，弗使斗争而国家多难，其渐必有劫杀之乱矣。 人君好色，弗使风议而国家昏乱，其积至於淫洗之难矣。 民化其上，如水顺下，宜杜其原本，慎之细微，故秦庄有祈胁之祸，夏桀有妲已之乱也哉。 故圣人精诚别於内，好憎明於外，出言以副情，发号以明指。 内无偏僻，外绝爱憎，言出响应，令出风行。 是故刑罚不足以移风，杀戮不足以禁奸，可以德化，难以刑制。 唯神化为贵，精至为神，精之所动，若春气之生，秋气之杀。 其生也，暄然如春物得其生。 其死也，肃然如秋物终於死。 故生不祈报，死无归怨。 生之死之，以其无心也。 故君子者，其犹射者也，於此毫末，於彼寻文矣。 故理人者慎所以感之。 故君子理人，犹如射也，发矢之际，期於中的，及其至垛，以县寻文所。 毫厘之差，天地县隔。 老子曰：悬法设赏而不能移风易俗者，诚心不抱也。 法不可以禁民，唯至德可以易俗也。 故听其音则知其风，观其乐即知其俗，见其俗即知其化。 审音以知乐，审乐以知政，观政以知俗，观俗以知化。 夫抱真效诚者，感动天地，神踰方外，令行禁止，诚通其道而达其意，虽无一言，天下万民，禽兽鬼神与之变化，夫圣人之治天下，民从其化，有若转丸。 禁奸忒，其犹止方。 故不恃之德，不言之教，禽兽神鬼无不悦服。 况於人也？ 故太上神化，归自然也。 其次使得不为非，立法以制。 其下赏贤而罚暴。 道德既废，赏罚始行。 进贤之路开，则不肖者亦有居。 其位去，暴之端起，则贤者亦有受其戮矣。 故知非法不明，守之者滥，衡#6非不平，用之者弱。 老子曰：大道无为，无为即无有，无有者不居也，不居者即处无形，无形者不动，不动者无言也，无言者即静而无声无形，无声无形者，视之不见，听之不闻，是谓微妙，是谓至神，绵绵若存，是谓天地之根。 无为者，为而不恃，故曰无为。 无言者，言而不矜，故曰无声。 无形何听？ 无色何视？ 可谓神微。 独立不改，绵绵常存，为天地根。 道无形无声，故圣人强为之形，以一字为名天地之道。 此言得道之要。 大以小为本，多以少为始。 有生於无，多起於一。 夫推本则返於无形，寻末则惑於多数。 故知返则以无为为宗，感多则求一为主也。 天子以天地为品，言广大也。 以万物为资，无不有也。 功德至大，势名至贵，二德之美，与天地配，故不可不轨，大道以为天下母。 自四海之尊与天地相匹，安得不轨以乱乎？ ，天经者也。
chunks.translated_text:
Laozi said: The yang of winter’s sun, the yin of summer’s shade—things turn to them without being driven to excess. This is the spontaneous arrival of utmost refinement, unsummoned yet come, departing without going. In the profound and obscure, though one knows not how it is done, success is achieved of itself.

The yang of winter’s sun—those who are cold draw near. The yin of summer’s shade—those who are scorched find relief. Thus the sage governs the world: yin and yang are without sentiment, and the sage too is without sentiment. Things embrace of themselves, people return of themselves. Thus they come without being summoned, depart without being sent away.

To await the eye before seeing, to await speech before issuing commands—governance becomes difficult. Gaoyao was mute yet served as Grand Judge, and the world knew no cruel punishments—what need was there for words? Shikuang was blind yet served as Grand Minister, and the state of Jin knew no disorder—what need was there for sight? The command that requires no speech, the vision that requires no seeing—this is how the sage becomes a teacher.

To transform without speaking, so that below there are no cruel punishments—why trouble with words? To govern without seeing, so that Jin knows no disorder—what need is there for sight? Thus, without awaiting the eye to see, without needing speech to command—this is how the sage becomes a teacher.

The people’s transformation by their superior does not follow his words but follows his conduct. In high antiquity, one acted without speaking; in later ages, one speaks without acting. Thus when a ruler favors valor, though he does not incite strife, the state will face many crises, and gradually there will arise the chaos of robbery and murder. When a ruler favors beauty, though he does not encourage licentious talk, the state will fall into darkness and disorder, and over time there will come the calamity of debauchery and ruin.

The people’s transformation by their superior is like water flowing downward. One must block the source and be vigilant in small matters. Thus Duke Zhuang of Qin suffered the disaster of forced abdication, and Jie of Xia brought about the chaos of Daji. Therefore the sage refines sincerity within and clarifies likes and dislikes without. His words match his feelings, his decrees make his intent clear. Within, there is no partiality; without, there is no favoritism or aversion. Words issue and echoes respond; commands go forth and the wind carries them.

Thus punishments are not enough to shift customs, executions are not enough to suppress villainy. One may transform through virtue, but it is difficult to control through penalties. Only spiritual transformation is precious. Utmost refinement is spirit. Where refinement moves, it is like the qi of spring giving life or the qi of autumn bringing death. In life, it is warm as spring things receiving their growth. In death, it is solemn as autumn things reaching their end.

Thus in life there is no seeking of reward, in death no harboring of resentment. Life and death come from its being without intent. Therefore the noble person is like an archer: here, a hair’s breadth; there, a span’s mark. Thus one who governs others must be cautious in how he influences them.

Therefore the noble person governing others is like an archer: when the arrow is loosed, he aims for the target, and when it reaches the butt, he measures the span’s mark. A deviation of a hair’s breadth is as distant as heaven from earth.

Laozi said: To hang laws and set rewards yet fail to shift customs and change habits is because sincerity is not embraced. Laws cannot restrain the people; only utmost virtue can transform customs. Thus by listening to their music one knows their customs; by observing their music one knows their manners; by seeing their manners one knows their transformation.

Examine the sound to know the music, examine the music to know the governance, observe the governance to know the customs, observe the customs to know the transformation. One who embraces truth and offers sincerity moves heaven and earth, and spirits transcend beyond the four directions. Commands are obeyed and prohibitions observed. Sincerity penetrates the Way and conveys its intent. Though not a word is spoken, the myriad people of the world, birds and beasts, ghosts and spirits, all change with him.

Thus the sage’s governance of the world: the people follow his transformation as if rolling a ball. To forbid villainy and error is like halting a square object. Therefore, with virtue that does not rely on force, with teachings that require no words, even birds and beasts, spirits and ghosts, have none who are not pleased and submissive—how much more so for people?

Thus the highest is spiritual transformation, returning to spontaneity. Next is enabling people not to do wrong, establishing laws to regulate. The lowest is rewarding the worthy and punishing the violent. When the Way and virtue are abandoned, rewards and punishments begin. When the path to advancing the worthy is opened, the unworthy also find places. When their positions are lost, the seeds of violence arise, and even the worthy may suffer execution.

Thus one knows that without clear laws, those who uphold them become excessive; without an even balance, those who use it become weak.

Laozi said: The great Way is non-action. Non-action is non-possession. One who does not possess does not abide. One who does not abide dwells in formlessness. One who is formless does not move. One who does not move does not speak. One who does not speak is still and without sound or form. Without sound or form, it cannot be seen when looked at, cannot be heard when listened to. This is called the subtle and wondrous, the utmost spirit. Continuous as if existing—this is called the root of heaven and earth.

Non-action is acting without reliance, thus it is called non-action. No speech is speaking without pride, thus it is called no sound. Without form, what is there to hear? Without color, what is there to see? This may be called spiritually subtle. Standing alone without change, continuous and ever-present—it is the root of heaven and earth.

The Way is without form or sound, thus the sage forcibly gives it form, using a single word to name the Way of heaven and earth. This speaks of grasping the essentials of the Way. The great takes the small as its root, the many take the few as their beginning. Being arises from non-being, the many arise from the one.

Tracing back to the origin returns to formlessness; pursuing the branches leads to confusion by multiplicity. Thus knowing to return takes non-being as its foundation; sensing multiplicity seeks the one as its master.

The Son of Heaven takes heaven and earth as his standard—this speaks of their vastness. He takes the myriad things as his resources—there is nothing he does not possess. His merit and virtue are utmost, his power and name are most noble. The beauty of these two virtues matches heaven and earth. Thus he cannot but follow the great Way as the mother of the world.

From the honor of the four seas to matching heaven and earth—how could he not follow it to avoid disorder? This is the heavenly constant.

Grasping the essentials to observe the world, the sentiments of people can be discerned. Holding the jade pivot to observe the great movements, the Way of heaven can be illuminated. chunks.original_text: 老子曰：赈穷补急，则名生起利，不行小惠。 除害即功成。 不有其功者善。 世无灾害，虽圣无所施其德，上下和睦，虽贤无所立其功。 时有灾害，圣人平之。 国有祸乱，贤以定之。 今灾害不生，祸乱不作，虽圣无作圣之陛，虽贤无立功之地也。 故至人之治，含德抱道，推诚乐施，无穷之智，寝说而不言，天下莫知贵其不言者。 鼓腹击壤，不知帝力。 故道可道，非常道也，名可名，非常名也。 无名之道，道之至也。 有名之道，名之天下也。 故以道可道，非道也。 以名可名，非名也。 着於竹帛，缕於金石，可传於人者，皆其粗也。 华而多饰。 三皇五帝三王，殊事而同心，异路而同归。 言虽异时殊治，其归於道，一也。 末世之学者，不知道之所体一，德之所总要，取成事之迩，跪坐而言之，虽博学多闻不免於乱。 今之学者，不原其本，不体於要，不究其理，而寻其迹，务在广闻，只益生乱也。 老子曰：心之精者，可以神化而不可说道，其神化者，不可说以非道。 圣人不降席而匡天下，情甚於呼。 夫呼声可闻，不过数少。 政令一出，天下咸服也。 故同言而信，信在言前也，同令而行，诚在令外也。 与民同忧，故言至而信，信以前立矣，莫敢不应也。 与民同利，故令行而诚，诚以外发，无有违者也。 圣人在上，民化如神，情以先之。 县得彼意，所应如神。 动於上，不应於下者，情令殊也。 夫饥者利食，寒者思裘。 今饥者与裘，寒者遗食，上令既乖，下情安附也？ 三月婴兄未知利害，而慈母爱之愈笃者，情也。 赤子之心，岂言饥饱？ 慈母规候之情，察其燥湿而恩育之。 夫人主抚百姓如爱赤子，何忧天下不治，四海不平？ 故言之用者变，变乎小哉； 不言之用者变，变乎大哉。 言有言，言则小。 言无言，言则大。 信君子之言，忠君子之意，忠信形於内，感动应乎外，贤圣之化也。 言忠信，由是君子本意非有忘也。 故形於内而动於外，虽贤圣无不从也。 老子曰：子之死父，臣之死君，非出死以求名也，恩心藏於中，而不违其难也。 子死父难，臣死君难，非矫世求誉，特以恩覆之，甚而忘其身，直趋其难，诚发於中也。 君子之憯怛，非正为也，自中出者也。 亦察其所行。
chunks.translated_text:
Laozi said: Relieving poverty and aiding the urgent brings forth fame and profit, yet one should not practice petty kindness. Removing harm is where merit is accomplished. Not claiming merit as one’s own—this is goodness.

When the world knows no disasters or harms, even sages have no virtue to apply; when superiors and inferiors are in harmony, even the worthy have no merit to establish. When disasters arise, sages pacify them; when a state falls into calamity and chaos, the worthy settle it. Yet if disasters do not arise and chaos does not stir, even sages have no throne from which to act as sages, and even the worthy have no ground on which to establish merit.

Thus the governance of the perfected person embraces virtue and holds to the Dao, extending sincerity and delighting in bestowal. With boundless wisdom, they rest in silence and do not speak, and none in the world know the value of their non-speaking. They drum their bellies and strike the earth, unaware of the emperor’s power.

Thus the Dao that can be spoken is not the constant Dao; the name that can be named is not the constant name. The Dao without name is the utmost Dao; the Dao with name is the name of the world. Therefore, the Dao that can be spoken is not the Dao; the name that can be named is not the name.

That which is inscribed on bamboo and silk, carved into metal and stone, and transmitted to others—all these are but its coarse aspects, flowery and overly adorned. The Three Sovereigns, Five Emperors, and Three Kings followed different affairs yet shared the same heart, took different paths yet reached the same destination. Though their words differed and their governance varied with the times, their return to the Dao was one.

Scholars of the latter age do not know that the Dao is embodied in unity, that virtue gathers in essentials. They seize upon the immediacy of accomplished matters, kneel and sit to discourse upon them—though learned and widely informed, they cannot escape disorder. Scholars of today do not trace back to the root, do not embody the essentials, do not investigate the principle, but instead follow the traces, striving for broad knowledge, only adding to the chaos.

Laozi said: The essence of the heart can work spiritual transformations but cannot be spoken of as the Dao. Its spiritual transformations cannot be explained as non-Dao. The sage does not descend from his seat yet rectifies the world, his care surpassing even a shout. A shout can be heard, but only by a few; when a decree is issued, the whole world submits.

Thus when words are the same, trust lies before the words; when commands are the same, sincerity lies beyond the command. Sharing the people’s sorrows, words reach trust, for trust is established beforehand—none dare not respond. Sharing the people’s benefits, commands are carried out with sincerity, for sincerity arises externally—none dare disobey.

When the sage is above, the people are transformed as if by spirit, for sentiment precedes them. Grasping their intent, responses come as if by spirit. If one acts above yet receives no response below, it is because sentiment and decree diverge. The hungry seek food, the cold long for fur. If one gives fur to the hungry and food to the cold, the decree is already contrary—how can the people’s sentiment attach to it?

A three-month-old infant knows not of benefit or harm, yet the loving mother’s care grows ever more earnest—this is sentiment. The heart of a newborn child does not speak of hunger or fullness, yet the compassionate mother observes its signs, discerns its dryness or dampness, and nurtures it with kindness. If the ruler of men cherishes the hundred clans as he loves a newborn child, what worry is there that the world will not be governed, that the four seas will not be at peace?

Thus the use of words brings change—change in small matters. The use of non-words brings change—change in great matters. Words that speak of words are small; words that speak of no-words are great. Trusting a noble person’s words, being loyal to a noble person’s intent, loyalty and trust take shape within and move responses without—this is the transformation of the worthy and sage.

Loyalty and trust arise from the noble person’s original intent, not from forgetfulness. Thus when they take shape within and move without, even the worthy and sage cannot but follow.

Laozi said: A son’s death for his father, a minister’s death for his lord—these are not acts of seeking fame through death. The heart’s kindness is stored within, and they do not shirk from difficulty. A son dies for his father’s peril, a minister dies for his lord’s peril—not to feign virtue for the world’s praise, but because kindness covers them so deeply that they forget themselves, rushing straight into peril. Their sincerity arises from within.

The noble person’s sorrow is not for outward correctness but arises from within. One must examine their conduct.

chunks.original_text: 憯怛，谓刑法也。 刑戮，非正道也。 所以惩恶劝善，不得已而行之，不可滥也。 圣人不惭於景，贵不为非。 君子慎其独也，谓不欺暗窒也。 舍近期远塞矣。 近不求己，远而求人，不谓窒塞。 故圣人在上，则民乐其治，在下则民慕其意，志不忘乎欲利人也。 志在利人，人皆悦慕也。 老子曰：勇士一呼，三军皆辟，其出之诚也。 勇者一呼，万人皆骇。 贤者治世，天下所望也。 唱而不和，意而不载。 中必有不合者也。 所宗者异故也。 不下席而匡天下者，求诸己也，夫忧乐与民同，好恶与民等，故省诸己，可以化人也。 故说之所不至者，容貌至焉，虽未违其精微，可仿佛其容貌。 容貌所不至者，感忽至焉，感乎心发而成形，可以心灵感，不以状貌诘#7也。 精之至者可形接，不可以照期。 形百无形，至精之精，无不生形，而形见焉，照不求精，而精存矣。 老子曰：言有宗，事有本，失其宗本，伎能虽多，不如寡言。 以道为宗，以德为本，离宗失本，故多不如寡也。 害众者倕而使断其指，以明大巧之不可为也。 夫巧藏於心，不在於指，绝其不可得也。 由道在心，明非闳言，得若贵言，为道不可冀也。 故匠人智为不以能以时闭不知闭也，故必杜而后开。 匠人，工人也。 闭为局，镭夫至巧，故善以智闭也，莫能启，拙者专以力捍，虽壮必开。 比谕知用穷微。 力不足任也。 老子曰：圣人之从事也，所由异路而同归，今古虽殊，治则一也。 存亡定倾若一志不忘乎欲利人也。 亡者存之，倾者安之，岂唯闰已，常在利人。 故秦楚燕魏之歌，异声而皆乐，九夷八狄之哭，异声而皆哀。 夫歌者乐之征，哭者哀之效也，惜於中，发於外，故在所以感之矣。 声气相应，悲欢相召，故歌虽异国而皆乐，哭乃殊方而共悲也。 圣人之心，日夜不忘乎欲利人，其泽之所及亦远矣。 利人不已，泽乃遐临。 老子曰：人无为而治，有为也，即伤无为而治者，为无为； 为者不能无为也，不能无为者，不能有为也。 言无为者还是有为，有为即非，无为而治也。 唯有为而不为，即无为。 人无言而神有言也，即伤无言而神者，载无言则伤有神之神者。 神贵无言，圣尚不作。 言则迹见，为则人之粗，唯两无伤，能全於道也。 文子曰：名可强立，功可强成。 劝勉之道。 昔南荣趎老子弟子。 耻圣道而独亡於己，南见老子，受教一言，精神晓灵，屯闵条达勤苦，十日不食，如享太牢。 既受一言，精思十日，忘饥味道，如享太牢也。 是以明照海内，名立后世，智略天地，察分秋毫，称誉华语，至今不休，此谓名可强立也。 至言已受群疑，顿销若太阳回照，暗室俱明也。 故田者不强，困仓不满； 官御不励，诚心不精； 将相不强，功烈不成； 王侯懈怠，后世无名。 自庶人至於王侯，未有不勤励而能使仓廪实，功名着也。 至人潜行譬犹雷霆之藏也，随时而举事，因资而立功，进退无难，无所不通。 夫大人之道，其隐也寂然，天下莫能见其行也。 雷动，天下无不闻，进无喜容，退无惭色，是谓大道也。 夫至人精诚内形，德流四方，见天下有利也，喜而不忘天下有害也，怵若有丧。 喜则受利，忧其遇害。 夫忧民之忧者，民亦忧其忧，乐民之乐者，民亦乐其乐，故忧以天下，乐以天下，然而不王者，未之有也。
chunks.translated_text:
Sorrow and distress refer to penal law. Execution and punishment are not the proper Way. They are employed only to punish evil and encourage good, as a last resort, and must not be wantonly applied. The sage feels no shame before the sun and moon; the noble do not commit wrongdoing. The noble person is cautious in solitude, meaning they do not deceive even in darkness and seclusion. To abandon what is near and seek what is distant is to invite obstruction. To neglect self-cultivation while demanding it of others is to invite blockage.

Thus when the sage is in high position, the people delight in their governance; when in low position, the people admire their intent, for their resolve never wavers from desiring to benefit others. With their resolve set on benefiting others, all people rejoice and admire them.

Laozi said: When a brave warrior lets out a single cry, the entire army retreats—such is the power of his sincerity. A single shout from the brave strikes terror into ten thousand. The worthy govern the age, and all under heaven look to them. If one sings and none respond, or offers counsel and none bear it, there must be discord within. For their principles differ from others’. One who corrects all under heaven without leaving their seat seeks the cause within themselves. When joy and sorrow are shared with the people, and likes and dislikes are aligned with them, then by examining oneself, one can transform others.

Thus where persuasion does not reach, one’s demeanor does; though it may not convey the subtlest essence, it can approximate one’s bearing. Where demeanor does not reach, subtle influence does—arising from the heart and taking form, it moves through spiritual resonance, not through outward appearance. The utmost refinement can be perceived through form, yet cannot be forced into clarity. Though form arises from the formless, the purest essence gives birth to all forms, making them manifest. One does not seek refinement, yet refinement resides within.

Laozi said: Words have their source, affairs have their root. Lose the source and root, and no matter how many skills one possesses, it is better to speak little. Take the Dao as the source and virtue as the root; depart from them, and abundance is no match for simplicity. To harm the many, Yu the craftsman would sever his own finger to demonstrate that great skill cannot be forced. True skill resides in the heart, not in the fingers—cutting off what cannot be attained. When the Dao is in the heart, clarity does not depend on grand words. To value words as if they were the Dao is to hope in vain for the Dao.

Thus the craftsman’s wisdom lies not in their ability but in knowing when to close. The craftsman—an artisan—closes with skill, for the most adept know how to seal tightly, so none can open. The unskilled rely solely on brute force, and though strong, they will inevitably fail. This illustrates the exhaustion of subtle wisdom, for strength alone is insufficient.

Laozi said: The sage’s undertakings may follow different paths, yet they converge in the same end. Though past and present differ, governance remains the same. Preservation and ruin, stability and collapse—if one’s resolve never wavers from desiring to benefit others, then the ruined are preserved, the collapsed are stabilized. Is this concern only for oneself? It is always for the benefit of others.

Thus the songs of Qin, Chu, Yan, and Wei differ in sound yet all express joy; the wails of the Nine Yi and Eight Di differ in sound yet all convey sorrow. Song is the manifestation of joy, weeping the expression of sorrow—concealed within, it emerges without, and thus the means of moving others. Sound and breath resonate, sorrow and joy summon one another. Therefore, though songs differ by nation, all share in joy; though wails vary by region, all share in grief.

The sage’s heart never ceases, day or night, from desiring to benefit others. The reach of their virtue is thus vast. By unceasingly benefiting others, their influence extends far and wide.

Laozi said: When people act without contrivance, there is governance. To act is to harm the governance of non-action. To practice non-action is to act; those who cannot act without contrivance cannot truly act. To speak of non-action is still to act; to act is to depart from the governance of non-action. Only by acting without acting is there true non-action.

When people remain silent, the spirit speaks—yet to cling to silence harms the spirit’s true nature. The spirit values silence; even the sage does not force speech. Words reveal traces, actions reveal the coarse. Only when both are unharmed can the Dao be preserved whole.

Wenzi said: A name can be forcibly established, merit can be forcibly achieved—this is the way of encouragement. Formerly, Nanrong Chu, a disciple of Laozi, felt shame that the sagely Dao was absent within himself. He traveled south to see Laozi and received a single teaching. His spirit became enlightened, and though he endured hardship and toil, fasting for ten days, he savored the Dao as if feasting on the finest delicacies. Having received a single teaching, he meditated for ten days, forgetting hunger and tasting the Dao as if enjoying a grand banquet.

Thus his wisdom illuminated all within the seas, his name endured through later generations, his intelligence and strategy spanned heaven and earth, his discernment was as keen as distinguishing autumn down. His praises and eloquent words continue unceasing to this day—this is what it means for a name to be forcibly established. The ultimate teaching, once received, dissolves all doubts like the sun’s reflection illuminating a dark room.

Thus the farmer who does not exert himself will not fill his granary; the official who does not strive will not refine their sincerity; the general and minister who do not exert themselves will not achieve great deeds; the king and lord who are indolent will leave no name for posterity. From commoners to kings and lords, none have filled their granaries or made their names illustrious without diligence and effort.

The perfected person acts in concealment, like thunder hidden away. They act in accordance with the times, establish merit through available resources, advance and retreat without difficulty, and nothing is impassable. The great person’s Dao is hidden and still—none under heaven can perceive their actions. Yet when thunder strikes, none under heaven fail to hear it. They advance without elation, retreat without shame—this is the great Dao.

The perfected person’s essence and sincerity take form within, their virtue flowing to the four directions. Seeing benefit for all under heaven, they rejoice yet do not forget the harm that may befall them, trembling as if in mourning. They welcome benefit yet fear encountering harm. One who sorrows with the people’s sorrow will have the people sorrow with their sorrow; one who rejoices with the people’s joy will have the people rejoice with their joy. Thus to sorrow with all under heaven and rejoice with all under heaven—yet fail to become king—has never been.

A son dies for his father’s peril, a minister dies for his lord’s peril—not to feign virtue for the world’s praise, but because kindness covers them so deeply that they forget themselves, rushing straight into peril. Their sincerity arises from within.

The noble person’s sorrow is not for outward correctness but arises from within. One must examine their conduct.

chunks.original_text: 忧於民，民亦忧之。 乐於民，民亦乐之。 忧乐共之，民不戴者，未之有也。 圣人之法始於不可见，终於不可及，德义无方，终始无际。 处於不倾之地，立身无为之地。 积於不尽之仓，用之不既，戴於不竭之府，运之而无穷也。 出令如流水之原，使民於不争之官，令行则民知禁，事省则官无讼。 开必得之门。 安其所业。 不为不可成，不求不可得，不处不可久，不行不可复。 大人之令，动必有益，作则兴利，不处不久，不求不复。 大人行可说之政，而人莫不顺其命，命顺则从小而致大，命逆则以善为害，以成为败。 其政教，顺之以凶为吉，逆则以大为小。 夫所谓大丈夫者，内强而外明，内强如天地，外明如日月，天地无不覆载，日月无不照明。 如天地之覆载，如日月之照明，是谓大丈夫也。 大人以善示人，不变其故，不易其常，天下听令如草从风。 革其故则俗难安，循其性则人易治。 草之从风，无敢违者。 政失於春，岁星盈缩，不居其常； 政失於夏，荧惑逆行； 政失於秋，太白不当，出入无常； 政失於冬，辰星不效其乡； 四时失政，镇星摇荡，日月见商，五星悖乱彗星出。 四时有差，五星失常，商见于天，灾及於人。 春政不失禾黍滋，夏政不失雨降时，秋政不失民殷昌，冬政不失国家宁康。 此明主不可失政。 君失其政，天降百殃。 君守其政，天降百祥。 一人之庆万民乐。 通玄真经卷之二竟 ＃1 兆：原作『为』，据瞿本改。 ＃2 自：瞿本作『罔』。 ＃3 不诚：瞿本作『以诚』。 ＃4 求：原作『忘』据瞿本改。 ＃5 赡：原作『瞻』，据瞿本改。 ＃6 衡：原本无，据瞿本增。 ＃7 诘原作『结』，据瞿本改。 通玄真经卷之三 默希子注
chunks.translated_text:
To sorrow with the people is to have the people sorrow with you; to rejoice with the people is to have the people rejoice with you. One who shares sorrow and joy with the people yet fails to win their allegiance has never been.

The sage’s law begins where it cannot be seen and ends where it cannot be reached. Their virtue and righteousness know no bounds, their beginning and end no limits. They dwell in unshakable ground, stand where non-action prevails. They amass from inexhaustible granaries, using without depletion; they draw from unfailing treasuries, circulating without end.

Their decrees flow like the source of a river, guiding the people to offices of no contention. When commands are issued, the people know the prohibitions; when affairs are simplified, officials have no disputes. They open doors that must be entered, secure the people in their occupations. They do not attempt what cannot be accomplished, do not seek what cannot be obtained, do not dwell where they cannot endure, do not act where they cannot recover.

The great person’s decrees bring only benefit when enacted, and what they establish endures. They do not dwell where they cannot last, do not seek what cannot be regained. The great person enacts governance that brings joy, and none fail to follow their commands. When commands are obeyed, one advances from small to great; when commands are defied, good becomes harm and success becomes failure.

In their governance and teaching, obedience turns misfortune to fortune, while defiance reduces the great to the small. The one called a true great person is inwardly strong and outwardly luminous—internally as steadfast as heaven and earth, externally as radiant as sun and moon. Heaven and earth cover and bear all, sun and moon illuminate all. To be like heaven and earth in covering and bearing, like sun and moon in illumination—this is the true great person.

The great person shows goodness to others without altering their fundamental ways, without changing their constant principles. All under heaven follow their commands as grass bends to the wind. To alter the fundamentals unsettles customs; to follow nature makes the people easy to govern. Grass bends to the wind—none dare defy it.

When governance errs in spring, Jupiter waxes and wanes, abandoning its regular path. When governance errs in summer, Mars moves in reverse. When governance errs in autumn, Venus appears where it should not, its movements erratic. When governance errs in winter, Mercury fails to appear in its proper place. When the four seasons lose their order, Saturn sways unsteadily, the sun and moon display omens, the five planets move in chaos, and comets appear. When the seasons are disordered and the five planets lose their regularity, celestial omens appear in the heavens, and disaster befalls humanity.

If spring governance is not lost, millet and grain flourish; if summer governance is not lost, rain falls in season; if autumn governance is not lost, the people prosper; if winter governance is not lost, the state enjoys peace and well-being. Thus the enlightened ruler must not lose proper governance. When the ruler loses governance, heaven sends down a hundred calamities. When the ruler upholds governance, heaven sends down a hundred blessings. The joy of one becomes the joy of ten thousand.

chunks.original_text: 九守 此篇有九目，故曰《九守》。 九者，易之数终。 明极则变，变则乖道。 守之者居，亢龙无悔，可越三清之表。 忽之者，则牝马不利，将沦九幽之下。 固宜守道，不可失常也。 老子曰：天地未形，窈窈冥冥，浑而为一，气象未分。 寂然清澄，重浊为地，精微为天，形质已具。 离而为四时，春生夏长，秋收冬藏。 分而为阴阳，刚柔立矣。 精气为人，粗气为虫，所本则一，所禀则异，气有清浊，物有精粗。 刚柔相成，万物乃生。 从是万化，至乎无穷。 精神本乎天，骨骸根于地，本乎天者，亲上； 本乎地者，亲下。 精神入其门，骨骸反其根，我尚何存。 入无穷之门，反造化之根，莫诚其真，孰云有我也？ 故圣人法天顺地，不拘於俗，不诱於人，以天为父，以地为母，阴阳为纲，四时为纪，翱翔天地，复蹈纪纲逍遥於自得之境，放旷於无为宅，俗不能拘，世不能诱也。 天静以清，地定以宁，万物逆之者死，顺之者生。 天无心於逆顺，人有生於祸败。 故静漠者神明之宅，虚无者道之所居。 道处於静默，神游於虚极。 夫精神者所受於天也，骨骸者所禀於地也。 天气清化而为精神，地气重疑而为骨骸，故言禀受。 道生一，天也。 一生二，地也。 二生三，人也。 三生万物。 变化广也。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 皆柔和气而和。 老子曰：人受天地变化而生，受生天地之间，而居万物之上。 一月而膏，凝也。 二月血脉，形兆胚也。 三月而胚，定府灵也。 四月而胎，五月而筋，六月而骨，七月而成形，开窍通明。 八月而动，神其降灵。 九月而躁，宫室列布，以定精也。 十月而生，万像成也。 形骸已成，五藏乃分。 肝主目，肾主耳，脾主舌，肺主鼻，胆主口。 五藏此唯四，形今说不同，未详。 外为表，中为里，头圆法天，足方象地。 一人之身，万像悉傋，不可轻也。 天有四时五行九曜三百六十日，人有四支五藏九窍三百六十节； 天有风雨寒暑，人有取与喜怒。 胆为云，肺为气，脾为风，肾为雨，肝为雷，人与天地相类，而心为之主。 心为身主，总统五藏、六府、四支、九窍之要，上通於天，下应於地，中合於万物。 所谓神。 百姓日用不知，知此道者，鲜矣。 耳目者日月也，血气者风雨也。 日月失行，薄蚀无光，风雨非时，毁拆生灾。 天有日月，不可不明； 风雨，不可不节。 不时不节，则为灾。 人有耳目，不可不清； 血脉，不可不平。 不和不平，则为病矣。 五星失行，州国受其殃。 五星所犯，分野受灾。 五藏受邪，一身生病。 天地之道，至闳以大，尚由节其章光，爱#1其神明，人之耳目，何能久熏而不息，精神何能驰骋而不乏。 天地至大，犹节四时、调五纬，护其神明。 况乎人役耳目，驰心虑而能全其性灵者乎？ 是故圣人守内而不失外。 内保精神，外全形体。 夫血气者，人之华也，五藏者，人之精也，血气专乎内而不外越，则胸腹充而嗜欲寡。 夫见表知里，视本知末，且嗜欲生乎中，则华色雕乎外； 精气和於内，而肌肤充乎外。 嗜欲寡，则耳目清而听视聪达，听视聪达谓之明。 夫聪无不察，明无不照，莫不由乎寡情杜欲也。 五藏能属於心而无离，则气意胜胜去。 而行不僻，精神盛而气不散，以听无不闻，以视无不见，以为无不成，任能正定其心，五藏不受於邪，则悖之气散，而精神之用明，微无不照，幽无不察，事无不济，为无不成也。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Nine Guardians**

This chapter contains nine sections, hence the title *The Nine Guardians*. Nine is the culminating number of the *Yi*. When clarity reaches its limit, change occurs, and change leads to deviation from the Dao. Those who guard it abide in stillness—like the dragon at its zenith, free from regret—and may transcend the Three Pure Realms. Those who neglect it, like a barren mare, will sink beneath the Nine Dark Abysses. Thus, one must guard the Dao and never lose constancy.

Laozi said: Before heaven and earth took form, all was dark and indistinct, merged as one, the qi and its manifestations undivided. Silent and limpid, the heavy and turbid settled as earth, the refined and subtle rose as heaven—thus were shapes and substances established. Separating, they became the four seasons: spring’s birth, summer’s growth, autumn’s harvest, winter’s storage. Dividing, they became yin and yang, and hardness and softness were set forth. Refined qi became humans, coarse qi became creatures. Their origin is one, yet their endowment differs; qi has purity and turbidity, things have refinement and coarseness. Through the interplay of hardness and softness, the myriad things are born. From this, transformations extend endlessly.

Spirit and essence derive from heaven; bones and flesh root in earth. That which derives from heaven inclines upward; that which derives from earth inclines downward. When spirit enters its gate and bones return to their root, what remains of me? Entering the gate of the boundless, returning to the root of creation, who, if not utterly sincere in their truth, can claim a self? Thus, the sage models heaven and follows earth, unbound by custom, unenticed by others. Heaven is their father, earth their mother; yin and yang their warp, the four seasons their weft. Soaring between heaven and earth, they tread the warp and weft, roaming in the realm of self-attainment, dwelling in the abode of non-action. Custom cannot bind them, the world cannot entice them.

Heaven is still and clear; earth is settled and tranquil. The myriad things that oppose them perish; those that accord with them live. Heaven has no intent regarding opposition or accord—yet humans bring upon themselves calamity and ruin. Thus, stillness and silence are the dwelling of spirit and clarity; emptiness and nothingness are the abode of the Dao. The Dao resides in quietude; spirit wanders in the utmost void.

Spirit and essence are received from heaven; bones and flesh are endowed by earth. Heaven’s qi, clear and transformative, becomes spirit; earth’s qi, heavy and congealing, becomes bones and flesh—hence the term "endowment." The Dao gives birth to the One: heaven. The One gives birth to the Two: earth. The Two give birth to the Three: humanity. The Three give birth to the myriad things. Their transformations are vast. The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang, harmonized by the qi between them. All are softened and harmonized by qi.

Laozi said: Humans receive the transformations of heaven and earth and are born between them, dwelling above the myriad things. In the first month, the essence congeals. In the second, blood and vessels form, and the embryo’s shape appears. In the third, the embryo takes form, and the residence of spirit is fixed. In the fourth, the fetus develops; in the fifth, the sinews; in the sixth, the bones; in the seventh, the form is complete, and the orifices open, granting clarity. In the eighth, movement begins, and spirit descends with its numinous power. In the ninth, restlessness arises as the palaces and chambers arrange themselves to secure the essence. In the tenth, birth occurs, and the myriad images are complete.

Once the physical form is fully shaped, the five viscera divide. The liver governs the eyes, the kidneys the ears, the spleen the tongue, the lungs the nose, and the gallbladder the mouth. Here, only four viscera are mentioned—modern accounts differ, and the details remain unclear. The exterior is the surface; the interior is the core. The head is round, modeling heaven; the feet are square, resembling earth. A single human body encompasses the myriad images—it must not be treated lightly.

Heaven has four seasons, five phases, nine luminaries, and three hundred sixty days; humans have four limbs, five viscera, nine orifices, and three hundred sixty joints. Heaven has wind, rain, cold, and heat; humans have taking and giving, joy and anger. The gallbladder corresponds to clouds, the lungs to qi, the spleen to wind, the kidneys to rain, and the liver to thunder. Humans resemble heaven and earth, with the heart as their master.

The heart governs the body, overseeing the five viscera, six bowels, four limbs, and nine orifices. Above, it connects to heaven; below, it responds to earth; in between, it harmonizes with the myriad things. This is what is called "spirit." The common people use it daily yet do not know it; those who understand this Dao are few.

The ears and eyes are the sun and moon; blood and qi are wind and rain. When the sun and moon lose their course, they dim and eclipse; when wind and rain are untimely, they destroy and bring disaster. Heaven has sun and moon, which must not be dim; wind and rain, which must be regulated. When they are untimely or unregulated, disaster follows. Humans have ears and eyes, which must be clear; blood and vessels, which must be balanced. When they are disharmonious or unbalanced, illness arises.

When the five stars lose their course, the states and regions suffer their misfortune. Where the five stars trespass, the corresponding lands endure calamity. When the five viscera are afflicted by evil, the whole body falls ill. The Dao of heaven and earth is vast and great, yet it still regulates its brilliance and cherishes its spirit and clarity. How can human ears and eyes endure constant stimulation without rest, or spirit and essence gallop without exhaustion?

Heaven and earth, though vast, regulate the four seasons and harmonize the five planets, protecting their spirit and clarity. How much more so for humans, who employ their ears and eyes and let their hearts and thoughts race—can they preserve their nature and spirit? Thus, the sage guards the inner and does not lose the outer, preserving spirit within and protecting the physical form without.

Blood and qi are humanity’s splendor; the five viscera are humanity’s essence. When blood and qi focus inward and do not stray outward, the chest and abdomen are full, and desires diminish. Observing the surface reveals the interior; seeing the root reveals the branch. When desires arise within, splendor fades without; when essence and qi harmonize within, the flesh and skin flourish without.

When desires are few, the ears and eyes are clear, and hearing and sight are keen—this is called "clarity." Clarity leaves nothing unperceived; brightness leaves nothing unilluminated. All arise from restraining passions and cutting off desires. When the five viscera remain aligned with the heart and do not stray, qi and intent prevail, and conduct is not perverse. When spirit is abundant and qi does not scatter, hearing leaves nothing unheard, sight leaves nothing unseen, and nothing is left unaccomplished.

By rightly settling the heart, the five viscera remain free from evil, wayward qi disperses, and the function of spirit and essence becomes bright. Nothing subtle is left unilluminated, nothing hidden is left unexamined, no affair is left unfinished, and no task is left unaccomplished.

When the ruler upholds governance, heaven sends down a hundred blessings. The joy of one becomes the joy of ten thousand.

chunks.original_text: 患祸无由入，邪气不能袭。 动用常正，祸患自亡。 内精不荡，外邪莫入。 故所求多者所得少，所见大者所知小。 自少以求多，即易因小以知大，则明。 夫孔窍者精神之户牖，血气者五藏之使候，决户牖，精神洞明玄鉴，通使俱，则五藏疏达而悖也。 故耳目淫於声色，即五藏动摇而不定，血气滔荡而不休，精神驰骋而不守，祸福之至，虽如丘山，无由识之矣。 惑於声色，役其精神，忘於彼而忘於此。 亦犹水之平也，则毫发之微可睹，人之蔽也，虽丘山之祸莫之见。 故圣人爱而不越，虽通嗜欲，务在节宣，不祈分外也。 圣人诚使耳目精明玄达，无所诱慕，意气无失清静，而少嗜欲，五藏便宁。 精神内守形骸而不越，即观乎往世之外，来事之内，祸福之间，可足见也。 圣人知嗜欲蔽塞聪明，故一心气而止乱，守精神而不越，则内外之情可见，祸福之兆自明也。 故其出弥远者，其知弥少，远徇於物，近贵其身，所弃者大，所得者小。 以言精神不可使外淫也，故五色乱目，使目不明，五音入耳，使耳不聪，五味乱口，使口生创，音爽。 外有所欲，内有所损。 趣舍滑心，使行飞扬，故嗜欲使人气淫，好憎使人精劳，不疾去之，则志气日耗。 精气泄漏，则形神日逝也。 夫人所以不能终其天年者，以其生生之厚。 厚生者，谓贪餐无厌。 只求快心诚自疏也。 夫唯无以生为者，即所以得长生。 无以生为不厚生，不厚生者，不处必死之地也。 天地运而相通，万物总而为一，能知一，即无一之不知也，不能知一，即无一之能知也。 自天地万物，轮转无穷皆乘一而有万类，虽差，同根于一。 故知万物为一，理无不悉。 不知万物为一，则触事皆失。 吾处天下，亦为一物，而物亦物也，物之与物，何以相物。 此明物我玄同，好僧无主。 故云吾处天下，亦天下之一物耳。 同为一物，何以相物，物我两忘，是非安继，故游刃虚，宗全真大横也。 欲生不可事也，憎死不可辞也，欲不可纵，事不可繁。 贱之不可憎也，贵之不可喜也。 贵贱以宜，好憎安在。 因其资而宁之，弗敢极也，弗敢极，即至乐极矣。 此一节总叙九守为治国修身之至诚，向道君子宜精详其旨也。 守虚九守一数 老子曰：所谓圣人者，因时而安其位，当世而乐其业。 安人之所不安，至安。 乐人之所不乐，至乐也。 夫哀乐者德之邪，好憎者心之累，喜怒者道之过，凡人则有，道者则无。 故其生也天行，其死也物化，生非我有，故谓天行。 死非我终，故谓物化。 静即与阴合德，动即与阳同波此动静不失其正也。 故心者形之生也，神者心之宝也。 神，心之舍也，人之所宝也。 形劳而不休即蹙，精用而不已则竭，是以圣人遵之，不敢越也。 形者，神之宅。 精者，气之灵。 相依而主，相违而死。 圣人贵之，不敢轻用也。 以无应有，必究其理，以虚受实，必穷其节，万物自无而生，无所不有。 天地以虚而受，无所不容也。 恬愉虚静，以终其命。 保虚静达生死。 无所疏，无所亲，其贵也，不可亲，其贱也，不可疏也。 抱德炀和，以顺於天，与道为际，与德为邻，不为福始，不为祸先，死生无变於己，故曰至神。 合乎道德，齐乎死生，福之不能佑，祸之不能倾，自非至神，安能若此？
chunks.translated_text:
Troubles and misfortunes have no means to enter, and wayward qi cannot invade. In movement and action, constancy in rectitude ensures calamities vanish of themselves. When inner essence does not dissipate, external evils cannot penetrate. Thus, those who seek much gain little, and those who perceive broadly know narrowly. To seek abundance from scarcity, to infer the great from the small—this is clarity.

The orifices are the doors and windows of spirit; blood and qi are the messengers and sentinels of the five viscera. Open the doors and windows, and spirit becomes luminous, its dark mirror bright; unobstruct the messengers, and the five viscera flow freely, free from disorder. When ears and eyes are indulgent in sounds and sights, the five viscera tremble and cannot settle, blood and qi surge and do not rest, spirit gallops and does not abide. Though blessings and misfortunes arrive like mountains, there is no means to perceive them.

Bewildered by sounds and sights, one enslaves the spirit, forgetting both self and other. Like still water, where even a hair’s breadth is visible, when one is obscured, even mountain-like calamities go unseen. Thus, the sage cherishes without transgressing; though desires may flow, they are ever restrained and regulated, never seeking what lies beyond. If the sage ensures ears and eyes are keen and profoundly penetrating, free from allure and longing, intent and qi unerring in clarity, with few desires, the five viscera find peace. Spirit guards within the form without straying, and one may observe beyond past ages, within future affairs, and between fortune and misfortune—all becomes fully visible.

The sage knows that desires obscure and obstruct clarity, so they unify heart and qi to halt disorder, guard spirit without transgression, and thus the truths of inner and outer become visible, the omens of fortune and misfortune naturally clear. Therefore, the farther one strays, the less one knows. Chasing distant things, prizing the near and valuing the self—what is discarded is great, what is gained is small. This speaks to spirit: it must not be allowed to stray outward. The five colors confuse the eyes, rendering them unclear; the five tones enter the ears, dulling their acuity; the five flavors disorder the mouth, causing sores and decay.

External desires bring internal harm. Pursuits and aversions disturb the heart, making conduct reckless. Desires cause qi to overflow, likes and dislikes exhaust the essence. If not swiftly abandoned, aspiration and qi daily diminish. When essence and qi leak away, form and spirit daily fade. The reason people cannot fulfill their natural lifespan is their excessive indulgence in life. "Excessive indulgence" means insatiable craving, seeking only gratification—truly, self-estrangement.

Only those who do not treat life as paramount attain longevity. Not treating life as paramount means not indulging excessively; not indulging excessively means not dwelling in places of certain death. Heaven and earth move and interpenetrate; the myriad things converge as one. To know the One is to know all; not to know the One is to know nothing. From heaven and earth to the myriad things, endless cycles all ride upon the One, giving rise to the ten thousand kinds. Though diverse, they share a root in the One. Thus, to know the myriad things as One is to comprehend all principles; not to know them as One is to fail in every encounter.

I dwell in the world as one thing among things—yet things are also things. How can things be distinguished from one another? This reveals the profound unity of self and other, where preferences and aversions have no ground. Thus, I dwell in the world as but one thing among the world’s things. Being of the same kind, how can they be distinguished? When self and other are both forgotten, right and wrong dissolve, and the blade glides through emptiness—this is the great mastery of preserving the true.

Desire for life cannot be served; aversion to death cannot be refused. Desires cannot be indulged, affairs cannot be multiplied. The lowly cannot be despised, nor the noble rejoiced in. Nobility and baseness find their proper place—where then lie likes and dislikes? Follow one’s endowment and find tranquility, daring not to exceed. Not exceeding, one attains the utmost joy.

This passage summarizes the Nine Guardians as the utmost sincerity for governing the state and cultivating the self. Those who turn toward the Dao should carefully ponder its essence.

**The Nine Guardians of Unity**
Laozi said: The so-called sage accords with the times and finds peace in their position, delights in their work amid the age. What others find uneasy, they make supremely peaceful; what others find joyless, they make supremely joyful. Grief and joy are deviations of virtue; likes and dislikes are burdens of the heart; pleasure and anger are transgressions of the Dao. The common person has them; the Daoist does not. In life, they follow the movement of heaven; in death, they transform with things. Life is not mine to possess—thus it is called "heaven’s movement." Death is not my end—thus it is called "transformation with things."

At rest, they unite with yin in virtue; in motion, they harmonize with yang in its current—this is movement and stillness without losing their rectitude. The heart is the life of the form; spirit is the treasure of the heart. Spirit is the abode of the heart, what people hold most precious. When the form labors without rest, it withers; when essence is used without cease, it depletes. Thus, the sage honors this and dares not transgress. The form is the dwelling of spirit; essence is the numen of qi. They depend on one another to preside; if they part, death follows. The sage values them and dares not use them lightly.

Responding to being with non-being, one must exhaust its principles; receiving the full with emptiness, one must fathom its limits. The myriad things arise from nothing, and nothing is not possessed. Heaven and earth receive with emptiness, and nothing is not contained. Serene, joyful, empty, and still, one fulfills their mandate. Preserving emptiness and stillness, one penetrates life and death. Nothing is estranged, nothing is favored. In nobility, one is not favored; in baseness, one is not estranged. Embracing virtue and kindling harmony, one accords with heaven, joins with the Dao as their boundary, and neighbors with virtue. They do not initiate fortune, nor precede calamity. Death and life bring no change to them—thus they are called "utterly spirit-like."

Accordant with the Dao and virtue, equal in death and life, fortune cannot aid them, nor calamity overthrow them. If not utterly spirit-like, how could one be thus?

By rightly settling the heart, the five viscera remain free from evil, wayward qi disperses, and the function of spirit and essence becomes bright. Nothing subtle is left unilluminated, nothing hidden is left unexamined, no affair is left unfinished, and no task is left unaccomplished.
