chunks.original_text: 得诸己者，在於平意。 意之平者，心不私外物，目不视采色，一其精神，和其喜怒，故得情尘不起，欲浪不翻。 人皆反性，而天下莫不承令也。 老子曰：阴阳陶冶万物，皆乘一炁而生。 上下离心，炁乃上蒸； 君臣不和，五谷不登。 春肃秋荣，冬雷夏霜，皆贼炁之所生也。 天地之间，一人之身也； 六合之内，一人之形也。 一人，天子也。 一人正，则天下获其安； 一人乱，则万姓罹其害。 故系於天地，通於六合，可不慎欤？ 故明於性者，天地不能胁也； 审於符者，怪物不能惑也。 性既合真，雷霆迫而不恐； 明以照物，阴阳惑之而莫疑也。 圣人由近以知远，以万里为一同。 得於内，明於外； 得於一，通於万。 炁蒸乎天地，礼义廉耻不设，万民莫不相侵暴虐，由在乎混冥之中也。 积善神明辅，而积恶神明咎。 然气类相召，善恶无差。 勿谓混冥之中无报应之效也。 廉耻陵迟及至世之衰，用多而财寡，事力劳而养不足，民贫苦而忿争生，是以贵仁。 仁以安之。 人鄙不齐，比周朋党，各推其与，怀机械巧诈之心，是以贵义。 义以断之。 男女群居，杂而无别，是以贵礼。 礼以正之。 性命之情，淫而相迫於不得已，则不和，是以贵乐。 乐以节之。 故仁义礼乐者，所以救败也，非通治之道也。 自贵仁己，不救弊之谓。 非为至德也。 诚能使神明定於天下，而心反其初，则民性善； 民性善，则天地阴阳从而包之，则财足而人赡，贪鄙忿争之心不得生焉。 仁义不用，而道德定於天下，而民不淫於采色。 故德衰然后饰仁义，和失然后谓声，礼淫然后饰容，故知道德，然后知仁义不足行也； 知仁义，然后知礼乐不足修也。 道德者，天下之大无不包也。 故有道者兼仁义礼乐，备而有之。 或者谓绝灭四者而曰有道非通论也。 夫圣王悯世之衰而无道德，故贵仁义礼乐，制节其性，和乐其情，全其节度，崇其敬让，使不敢踰越，以复道德也。 老子曰：清静之治者，和顺以寂寞，质真而素朴，闲静而不躁。 在内而合乎道，出外而同乎义，其言略而循理，其行悦而顺情，其心和而不伪，其事素而不饰。 不谋所始，不议所终。 安即留，激即行。 通体乎天地，同精乎阴阳，一和乎四时，明朗乎日月，与道化者为人。 此明清静素朴同乎天而合乎道，谓真人。 机巧诈伪，莫载乎心。 是以天覆以德，地载以乐，四时不失序，风雨不为虐，日月清静而扬光，五星不失其行，此清静之所明也。 真人之治，感於天地。 故日月清明而不武，凶悖不作也。 老子曰：治世之职易守也，其事易为也，其礼易行也，其责易赏也。 是以人不兼官，官不兼士，士农工商，乡别州异。 故农与农言藏，士与士言行，工与工言巧，商与商言数，是以士无遗行，工无苦事，农无废功，商无折货，各安其性。 异形殊类，易事而不悖，失业而贱，得志而贵#1。 《易繁辞》曰：乾以易知，坤以简能。 圣人无为而治，百姓不苦其役，则各安其业，俱乐其生。 故易理而不乱，四民得其所即贵，失其势即贱。 夫先知远见之人，才之盛也，而治世不以责於人。 不责成於人也。 博闻强志，口辩辞给人，知之溢也，而明主不求於下。 聪敏给数未必为忠正，不求在下位之也。 放世贱物，不从流俗，士之伉行也，而治世不以为化民。
chunks.translated_text:
「The attainment of **Dao/Way** within oneself lies in calming the mind.
The mind’s composure comes from the heart not being swayed by external things,
the eyes not fixated on colors,
unifying the spirit and harmonizing joy and anger,
thus attaining to the **qi**’s purity untainted by passions,
and the passions’ waves not rising.
All follow their nature in reverse,
yet none dare defy the sovereign’s command.

Laozi said:
Yin and Yang nurture all things,
all born riding upon the **One Qi**.
When ruler and subject are estranged, **qi** ascends and churns above;
When the sovereign and ministers are discordant, the five grains fail to flourish.
Spring’s harshness and autumn’s withering,
winter’s thunder and summer’s frost—
all these are born of the **Dao/Way**’s violators.

Between heaven and earth, a single person’s body;
Within the six extremes, a single person’s form.
One person—**the Son of Heaven**.
One person upright, and the world attains peace;
One person corrupt, and all peoples suffer harm.
Thus, bound to heaven and earth,
penetrating the six extremes,
how can one be too cautious?

Those who are clear about their nature
cannot be coerced by heaven and earth;
Those who are precise with **symbols/rituals**
cannot be misled by strange creatures.
When nature aligns with truth,
thunder and lightning press yet do not frighten.
When clarity illuminates all things,
Yin and Yang confuse yet none dare doubt.

The sage discerns the near to know the far,
treating ten thousand miles as one realm.
What is gained within is made manifest without;
What is mastered in the One permeates all.
When **qi** churns within heaven and earth,
rituals and propriety are not established,
and all peoples dare to encroach and oppress,
arising from the depths of **mixed chaos**.
Accumulated virtue receives the **spirit’s** aid,
accumulated vice incurs the **spirit’s** blame.
Yet **qi** of like kind calls to like—
virtue and vice hold no distinction.
Do not say that within **mixed chaos** there is no effect of retribution.

When shame and modesty decline,
and in times of societal decay,
efforts multiply yet wealth dwindles,
labor is excessive yet sustenance insufficient,
the people grow poor and wrathful, strife arising—
thus, **ren** is held in highest regard.
**Ren** brings peace.

When people are coarse and unaligned,
clustering in factions and cliques,
each advancing their own,
nurturing deceitful and cunning schemes—
thus, **yì/rightness** is held in highest regard.
**Yì** cuts through the excess.

When men and women dwell together in groups,
unrestrained and without distinction—
thus, **lǐ/ritual** is held in highest regard.
**Lǐ** brings order.

When natural impulses grow wild,
pressing upon one another beyond restraint,
disharmony arises—
thus, **yuè/music** is held in highest regard.
**Yuè** brings moderation.

Thus, **ren**, **yì**, **lǐ**, and **yuè**—
these are means to remedy failure,
not universal paths to governance.
To value **ren** alone
is not to save what is flawed—
this is not the **ultimate virtue/power**.

If truly one can establish the **spirit’s** clarity throughout the world,
and return the heart to its origin,
then the people’s nature becomes good.
When the people’s nature is good,
heaven and earth, Yin and Yang, follow and embrace them,
then wealth is abundant and people are nourished,
and the hearts of greed, coarseness, and strife cannot arise.
**Ren** and **yì** are not needed,
yet **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way** are established in the world,
and the people do not indulge in colors.

Thus, when **virtue/power** declines, **ren** and **yì** are adorned;
When harmony is lost, music is praised;
When **ritual/lǐ** grows licentious, outward decorum is emphasized.
Hence, one must first know **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**
before understanding that **ren** and **yì** are insufficient to practice;
One must first know **ren** and **yì**
before understanding that **ritual/lǐ** and **yuè/music** are insufficient to cultivate.

**Virtue/power** and **Dao/Way** encompass all beneath heaven.
Thus, those who possess the **Dao/Way** include **ren**, **yì**, **lǐ**, and **yuè**,
holding them all in readiness.

Some say to abandon and extinguish these four
and claim to possess the **Dao/Way**—
this is not a comprehensive view.

The sage-king pities the world’s decline,
yet without **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**,
thus values **ren**, **yì**, **lǐ**, and **yuè**,
restraining nature and harmonizing emotions,
preserving propriety and reverence,
exalting respect and yielding,
so none dare overstep—
to restore **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**.

Laozi said:
Governance through **qīngjìng**—
harmonious and yielding, yet tranquil and still,
simple and true, natural and unadorned,
quiet and undisturbed—
within, it aligns with the **Dao/Way**;
without, it conforms with **yì/rightness**.
Its words are few yet follow reason;
Its actions are pleasing yet accord with nature;
Its heart is harmonious yet unfeigned;
Its deeds are plain yet not ostentatious.
It does not plot beginnings,
nor debate endings.
At peace, it remains; when stirred, it acts.
Its body permeates heaven and earth,
its essence unites with Yin and Yang,
its harmony aligns with the four seasons,
its clarity shines like the sun and moon.
It follows the **Dao/Way**’s transformations—
this is the **true person**.

This is the **true person** who governs with **qīngjìng**,
aligning with heaven’s **Dao/Way** and harmonizing with the **Way**.
**Ren** is free from **jīqìao**—
deceit and artifice.

Thus, heaven covers with **virtue/power**,
earth bears with **yuè/music**,
the four seasons do not lose their order,
winds and rains do not act as disasters,
the sun and moon remain clear and radiant,
the five stars do not stray in their courses—
this is the clarity of **qīngjìng**.

The **true person**’s governance
responds to heaven and earth.
Thus, the sun and moon shine brightly yet do not force,
and calamities do not arise.

Laozi said:
The duties of governance in a **harmonious age** are easy to uphold,
its affairs are simple to execute,
its **ritual/lǐ** is straightforward to practice,
its rewards are clear to bestow.
Thus, one person does not hold multiple offices,
offices do not overlap with scholars,
scholars, farmers, artisans, and merchants
keep to their own districts and states.

Thus, farmers speak with farmers of **cáng/hidden matters**,
scholars speak with scholars of conduct,
artisans speak with artisans of skill,
merchants speak with merchants of calculations—
so scholars lack no proper action,
artisans suffer no laborious toil,
farmers waste no effort,
merchants lose no goods,
each finding contentment in their nature.

Diverse forms and natures,
simple yet not contradictory,
lose their occupation and become despised,
gain their ambition and become honored.
The *Easy Words of the Yi* say:
**Qián** is easy to know,
**Kūn** is simple in ability.
The sage governs without action,
the people do not weary of their labors,
each finding contentment in their work,
all rejoicing in their lives.

Thus, governance is easy yet not chaotic,
the four classes gain their due—
this is honored;
lose their standing—
this is degraded.

Those with foresight and distant vision
are the most talented,
yet in a **harmonious age**, no blame is assigned to them.
No blame is placed upon them.
Those with vast knowledge and strong resolve,
eloquent and quick-witted,
are those whose understanding overflows,
yet the wise ruler does not demand from those below.
The clever and quick are not necessarily loyal and upright—
this is because the ruler does not seek from those beneath him.

To abandon the world’s coarse and despised,
not conforming to common customs,
is the conduct of scholars,
yet in a **harmonious age**, this is not how the people are transformed.»

Water, when stirred, creates waves;
**qi**, when disordered, brings confusion.
Confused wisdom cannot be relied upon for rectitude,
turbulent water cannot be still.
Thus, the sage-king holds to the One
to regulate the emotions and nature of things.

The One is the most precious—
it has no fixed place in the world.
The sage-king entrusts himself to this boundlessness,
thus commanding the world’s fate.

chunks.original_text: 敖世忽俗，不可以为仪表。 故高不可及者，不以为人量； 行不可逮者，不可为国俗。 故人才不可专用而度量，道术可世传也。 此数者治世，士不可不察其才而用，唯通明道术，与时消息者则与为治。 故国治可与愚守也，而军旅可以法同也。 不待古之英隽而人自足者，因其所有而并用之。 治在适时，非求异见； 词尚体要，无烦饰辩。 但量能处位，无世无之。 岂待古贤，天下方治也？ 末世之法，高为量而罪不及也，重为任而罚不胜也，危为其难而诛不敢也。 民困於三责，即饰智而诈上，犯邪而行危，虽峻法严刑，不能禁其奸。 兽穷即触，鸟穷即啄，人穷即诈，此之谓也。 用其法而求其遇以诛其罪者，是为法杀人，非治人也。 怀忧惧即饰智而诬矫以求侥伟，由鸟兽穷蹙则拂然之心而忿不顾其生也。 故圣人责道不贵法也。 老子曰：雷霆之声，可以钟鼓象也； 风雨之变，可以音律知也。 大可睹者，可得而量也； 明可见者，可得而弊也； 声可闻者，可得而调也； 色可察者，可得而别也。 夫至大天地不能函也，至微神明不能见也。 夫风雨雷霆、形声色象，可以类知，可以建事。 及乎至大至微者，谓道也，天地不能容，神明不能究也。 及至建律历，别五色，异清浊，味甘苦，即朴散而为器矣。 立仁义，修礼乐，即德迁而为伪矣。 民饰智以惊愚，设诈以攻上，天下有能持之而未能有治之者也。 夫智能弥多而德滋衰，是以至人淳朴而不散。 夫至人之治，虚无寂寞，不见可欲，心与神处，形与性调，静而体德，动而理通，循自然之道，缘不得已矣。 漠然无为而天下和，淡然无欲而民自朴，不忿争而财足。 施者不得，受者不让，德反归焉，而莫之惠。 不言之辩，不道之道，若或通焉，谓之天府。 取焉而不损，酌焉而不竭，莫知其所求由出，朴散亡本，故圣人有作而调饰之，使反修其业，道乎自然，藏於天府，取之不减，与之不盈。 谓之摇光。 摇光者，资粮万物者也。 摇光斗标之望揭运於中，制以四方万物，主之以为资。 老子曰：天爱其精，地爱其平，人爱其情。 天之精，日月星辰，雷霆风雨也。 地之平，水火金木土也。 人之情，思虑聪明喜怒也。 故闭四关，止五道，即与道沦。 神明藏於无形，精气反於真，目明而不以视，耳聪而不以听，口当而不以言，心条通而不以思虑，委而不为，知而不矜，直性命之情，而知故不得害。 精存於目，即其视明； 存於耳，即其听聪； 留於口，即其言当； 集於心，即其虑通。 故闭四关，即终身无患，四肢九窍莫死莫生，是谓真人。 天之四关，日、月、星、辰。 五道，五行也。 言四时有节，五行有度，则天地清明，民物丰泰。 人之四关，心、口、耳、目也。 五道，谓五藏也。 夫精神存者，则四关不妄动； 五道不受邪聪视听明、言行无跌，故祸害无及於身，止死不系於怀，是真人得道所游之地。 地之生财，大本不过五行，圣人节五行，即治不荒。 圣人者，由节五情以和五行，故天下不乱，而况常人哉？ 老子曰：衡之於左右，无私轻重，故可以为平； 绳之於内外，无私曲直，故可以为正； 人主之於法，无私好憎，故可以为令。 德无所立，怨无所藏，是任道而合人心者也。 此三者，藉於无私，故平为之立，正为之存，令为之行；
chunks.translated_text:
The age of extravagance and neglect of customs cannot serve as a model.

Thus, those whose heights are unattainable should not be the measure for all;
those whose conduct is beyond imitation should not be the standard for the realm.

Therefore, talent cannot be monopolized or constrained by rigid measures,
while the Dao/Way and its methods may be passed down through generations.

These principles in a harmonious age—
scholars must discern their talents and employ them accordingly.
Only those who grasp the luminous Dao/Way and adapt with the times
can assist in governance.

Thus, when the realm is well-ordered, even the unlearned can uphold its ways,
and military formations can be standardized by law.

Without awaiting ancient sages, the people suffice in their own right—
utilizing what they possess and combining their strengths.

Governance lies in timely adaptation, not in seeking novelty;
eloquence should emphasize substance, not empty rhetoric or debate.

Yet if one measures ability and assigns positions appropriately,
there will never be a time without capable rulers.

Why wait for ancient worthies when the world is already well-ordered?

The laws of the declining age
set lofty standards yet fail to reach their mark,
impose heavy burdens yet cannot bear the punishment,
and create peril yet dare not execute.
The people, burdened by these three oppressions,
adorn their cunning to deceive the ruler,
pursue vice while courting danger—
though harsh laws and severe punishments are enforced,
they cannot suppress their deceit.

When beasts are cornered, they strike;
when birds are cornered, they peck;
when people are cornered, they deceive—
this is their nature.

To apply the law and punish only when crimes are committed
is to kill by law, not to govern.

Those filled with anxiety and fear
adorn their cunning, distort the truth, and scheme to gain advantage—
like birds and beasts driven to desperation,
their defiant hearts disregard their own lives.

Thus, the Sage values the Dao/Way over laws.

Laozi said:
*The thunder’s roar can be imitated by bells and drums;
the shifts of wind and rain can be understood through music’s tones.
What is vast and visible can be measured;
what is bright and apparent can be exhausted;
what is audible can be tuned;
what is discernible can be distinguished.

Yet the utmost vastness—heaven and earth cannot contain it;
the utmost subtlety—spirit and clarity cannot perceive it.

Wind, rain, thunder, and lightning—
their forms, sounds, colors, and symbols
can be categorized and applied to affairs.

But when it comes to the utmost vastness and subtlety—
this is the Dao/Way,
which heaven and earth cannot encompass,
which spirit and clarity cannot fathom.

When establishing laws and calendars,
distinguishing the five colors,
separating purity and turbidity,
discerning sweet and bitter tastes—
then the undifferentiated is dispersed into tools.

When establishing benevolence and righteousness,
refining rituals and music—
then virtue shifts into artifice.

The people adorn their cunning to astonish the ignorant,
employ deceit to attack their superiors—
though some may uphold these ways,
none can truly govern with them.

The more cleverness abounds, the more virtue declines—
thus, the perfect one remains pure and undivided.

The perfect one’s governance is
empty, silent, and tranquil—
seeing no desires,
the heart and spirit dwell in harmony,
the form and nature align,
stillness embodies virtue,
action flows with principle,
following the Dao/Way of nature
only when necessity arises.

Vague and effortless, yet the world harmonizes;
indifferent and desireless, yet the people return to simplicity.
Without contention, resources suffice.
The giver does not hoard,
the receiver does not refuse—
virtue returns naturally,
yet none can claim credit.

Speech without words,
the Dao/Way beyond explanation—
if one attains this,
it is called the Celestial Storehouse.

Take from it without depletion,
draw from it without exhaustion—
none know its source,
for the undifferentiated disperses and loses its origin.
Thus, the Sage acts and refines,
restoring them to their natural state,
concealing them in the Celestial Storehouse,
taking without diminishing,
giving without excess.

This is called *Yao Guang* [Shaking Brilliance].
*Yao Guang* is the resource for all things.
Its luminous radiance and luminous standard
are displayed within,
governing the ten thousand things of the four quarters,
commanding them as its provision.

Laozi said:
*Heaven cherishes its purity,
earth cherishes its levelness,
humans cherish their sincerity.
Heaven’s purity—
the sun, moon, stars, and constellations,
thunder and wind, rain and mist.
Earth’s levelness—
water, fire, metal, wood, and soil.
Human sincerity—
thought, perception, cleverness, joy, and anger.

Thus, closing the four gates,
halting the five pathways—
this aligns with the Dao/Way.

Spirit and clarity are hidden in the formless,
qi returns to its true essence.
The eyes see clearly yet do not gaze,
the ears hear keenly yet do not listen,
the mouth speaks appropriately yet does not speak,
the heart’s pathways are open yet do not deliberate.
Abandoning action, knowing without arrogance,
following nature’s essence,
one knows yet cannot be harmed.

When essence resides in the eyes, vision is clear;
when it resides in the ears, hearing is acute;
when it lingers in the mouth, speech is precise;
when gathered in the heart, thought is lucid.

Thus, closing the four gates
ensures a life free from calamity—
the limbs and orifices neither die nor live,
this is called the True Person.

Heaven’s four gates are the sun, moon, stars, and constellations.
The five pathways are the five phases.

Speaking of the four seasons having their due,
the five phases having their measure—
then heaven and earth are clear and bright,
and the people and creatures flourish.

Human four gates are the heart, mouth, ears, and eyes.
The five pathways are the five viscera.

When essence and spirit are preserved,
the four gates do not move recklessly;
the five pathways do not receive false stimuli—
vision is clear, hearing is acute,
speech and action are without fault—
thus, calamity and harm cannot reach the body,
and death does not dwell in the mind.
This is the domain where the True Person dwells in the Dao/Way.

Earth’s production of wealth
has no greater foundation than the five phases.
The Sage regulates the five phases,
and thus governance does not falter.

The Sage, by harmonizing the five emotions with the five phases,
prevents chaos in the world—
how much more so for ordinary people?

Laozi said:
*When balanced left and right,
there is no private preference for light or heavy,
thus it can serve as level.
When measured within and without,
there is no private bias for crooked or straight,
thus it can serve as upright.
When the ruler applies law,
there is no private favor or aversion,
thus it can serve as command.

Virtue has no fixed place,
grudges have no place to hide—
this is to entrust oneself to the Dao/Way
and align with human hearts.

These three principles—
relying on impartiality—
establish levelness,
preserve uprightness,
and enact command;

chunks.original_text: 不殒德於外，不匿怨於内，任道而死，百姓不知。 故为治者，知不与焉。 水戾破舟，木击折轴，不怨木石，而罪巧拙者，智不载也。 水无破舟之意，木无折轴之心，不怨木石，而罪巧拙者，非智之所为也。 明治国者不以智。 故以智治国者，国之贼也。 故道有智则乱，德有心则险，心有眼则眩。 息智即不乱，忘心即不险，绝视则不眩，皆忘之也。 夫权衡规矩，一定而不易，常一而不邪，方行而不留。 一日形之，万世传之，无为之为也。 夫衡非不平，绳非不直，用之者偏耳。 道非不虚，德非不明，修之者误耳。 一者无为也，百王用之，万世传之，为而不易也。 一者无为也，百王用之，万世传之而不易也。 凡无情无私，一以遇之者，虽终日应用，未尝为也。 斯道致治，正而有常。 不然，权之与量，岂一日制作而万世不能易哉？ 老子曰人之言日：国有亡主，世亡亡道。 人有穷而理无不通，故无为者，道之宗也。 得道之宗，并应无穷，夫国之亡者，何也？ 以无正道故亡也。 夫穷而能通者，道也，为而不侍者，德也，无为之宗应於无穷者也。 故不因道理之数而专己之能，其穷不远也。 独贤於已，不修其道，立见穷屈。 夫人君，不出户以知天下者，因物以识物，因人以知人。 故积力之所举，即无不胜也。 众智之所为，即无不成也。 千人之众无绝粮，万人之群无废功。 工无异伎，士无兼官，各守其职，不得相干，人得所宜，物得所安，是以器械不恶，职事不慢也。 因此物识彼物之情，度己身见他人之性。 善用众者，可以倾河置海，善用人者，可以尽心竭力。 夫债少易偿也，职寡易守也，任轻易劝也。 上操约少之分，下效易为之功，是以君臣#2久而不相厌也。 在於简易，故无劳厌。 老子曰：帝者体太一，太一者，以虚无为祖，清静为宗，故帝王宜体之。 王者法阴阳，运行有度。 霸者则四时，不失其宜。 君者用六律。 与物有节。 体太一者，明於天地之情，通於道德之伦； 聪明照於日月，精神通於万物； 动静调於阴阳，喜#3怒和於四时； 覆露皆道，溥洽而无私； 蜎飞蠕动，莫不依德而生； 德流方外，名声传乎后世。 玄古帝王以道治天下也。 法阴阳者，承天地之和，德与天地参光，明与日月并照，精神与鬼神齐灵； 戴圆履方，抱表寝绳，内能理身，外得人心，发施号令，天下从风。 五帝以德治天下也。 则四时者，春生夏长，秋收冬藏，取与有节，出入有量，喜怒刚柔，不离其理，柔而不脆，刚而不折，宽而不肆，肃而不悖，优游委顺以养群类其德舍愚而容不肖，无所私爱也。 三王以仁治天下也。 用六律者，生之与杀也，赏之与罚也，与之以夺也，非此无道也，伐乱禁暴，兴贤良废不肖，匡邪以为正，攘险以为平，矫枉以为直，明於施舍#4开塞之道，乘时因势，以服役人心者也。 五霸以义治天下也。 帝者，不体阴阳即侵； 王者，不法四时即削； 霸者，不用六律即辱； 君者，失准绳即废。 故小而行大，即穷塞而不亲； 大而行小，即狭隘而不容。 帝王之世，道德有优劣； 五霸之时，仁义有厚薄。 大小不得相逾。 老子曰：地广民众，不足以为强； 甲坚兵利，不可以恃胜； 城高池深，不足以为固； 严邢峻罚，不足以为威。
chunks.translated_text:
The Sage does not abandon virtue to the external world,
nor conceal grudges within.
To entrust oneself to the Dao/Way even unto death—
the common people remain unaware.

Thus, those who govern know not to interfere.

Water capsizes a boat, wood snaps an axle—
yet one does not blame the wood and stone,
but punishes the clumsy and the skilled.
This is not wisdom.

Water has no intent to capsize a boat,
wood no mind to snap an axle—
yet one blames the clumsy and the skilled,
for this is not the work of wisdom.

To govern a state with wisdom is to be its ruin.

Thus, when the Dao/Way is mixed with wisdom, there is chaos;
when virtue is mixed with intent, there is peril;
when the mind is mixed with perception, there is dizziness.
To cease wisdom is to avoid chaos,
to forget intent is to avoid peril,
to sever perception is to avoid dizziness—
all are acts of forgetting.

The scales and compasses, the square and the circle—
fixed and unchanging,
ever consistent and never crooked,
moving straight without hesitation.
Once shaped, they endure for ten thousand generations—
this is the Way of *wuwei* (non-action).

The scales are not unbalanced,
the plumb line not crooked—
yet those who wield them err.

The Dao/Way is not empty,
virtue not obscure—
yet those who cultivate it stray.

The One is *wuwei*—
used by a hundred kings,
transmitted for ten thousand generations,
yet never altered.

The One is *wuwei*—
used by a hundred kings,
transmitted for ten thousand generations without change.

All who act without emotion or private bias,
meeting the One in all things—
though they act all day,
never once do they act.

This Dao brings governance—
correct and unchanging.

Otherwise, how could the balance and measure
be crafted in a single day
yet never altered for ten thousand generations?

Laozi said:
*"The people say:
'A kingdom has a lost ruler,
an age has lost the Dao/Way.'

A person may reach exhaustion,
yet reason remains unblocked.
Thus, *wuwei* is the essence of the Dao/Way.

To grasp the essence of the Dao/Way
is to respond to the boundless.
Then why do kingdoms perish?
Because they lack the correct Dao/Way.

He who reaches exhaustion yet remains unblocked—
this is the Dao/Way.
To act without clinging—
this is virtue.
The essence of *wuwei* responds to the boundless.

Thus, if one does not follow the numbers of Dao/Way
and instead relies solely on one’s own ability,
exhaustion will come swiftly.

To pride oneself in one’s own virtue
while neglecting the Dao/Way—
ruin and humiliation will soon follow.

The sovereign need not leave his door
to know the world—
by observing things, he knows things;
by observing people, he knows people.

Thus, where strength is gathered, nothing is unconquerable;
where many minds unite, nothing is unachievable.

A thousand-strong force lacks no provisions,
a ten-thousand-strong host lacks no purpose.
Craftsmen have no conflicting skills,
scholars hold no dual offices—
each guards their duty,
none overstepping their bounds.
People find their proper place,
things find their natural rest—
thus tools are not despised,
duties not neglected.

By observing one thing, one knows the nature of another;
by measuring oneself, one discerns the nature of others.

He who skillfully uses the many
can divert rivers and fill seas;
he who skillfully uses people
can exhaust their hearts and strength.

Debt is light when few,
duties are easy when simple,
burdens are light when light—
thus the sovereign enforces minimal demands,
and the people perform with ease.
Hence, ruler and subjects endure without weariness.

This is the virtue of simplicity—
thus there is no labor or fatigue.

Laozi said:
*The Sage embodies the Great Unity.
The Great Unity takes emptiness and nothingness as its origin,
cleanness and stillness as its essence—
thus the Sage and king should embody it.

The king follows the patterns of yin and yang,
moving with measured rhythm.

The hegemon aligns with the four seasons,
never departing from their due.

The ruler applies the six *lü* (musical pitches),
harmonizing with all things in moderation.

To embody the Great Unity is to understand
the nature of Heaven and Earth,
to harmonize with the principles of virtue and the Dao/Way;
to shine with the clarity of sun and moon,
to resonate with the spirit of all things;
to move and rest in accord with yin and yang,
to rejoice and anger in harmony with the four seasons;
to cover all things with the Dao/Way,
spreading broadly without favor—
even the smallest creatures,
creeping or flying,
all depend on virtue to live.

Virtue extends beyond the realm,
and fame endures through the ages.
Thus, the ancient Sage-kings governed the world with the Dao/Way.

To follow yin and yang is to inherit
the harmony of Heaven and Earth,
to share brilliance with Heaven and Earth,
to shine with the radiance of sun and moon,
to resonate with the spirits of gods and ghosts;
to wear the round and tread the square,
to embrace the standard and sleep with the plumb line—
within, to govern the body;
without, to win the hearts of people.
When orders are issued, the world follows like the wind.

The Five Emperors governed the world with virtue.

To align with the four seasons is to
take and give in due measure,
to enter and exit with restraint—
joy and anger, firmness and gentleness,
never straying from principle.
Gentle yet unbreakable,
firm yet unfractured,
broad yet not licentious,
solemn yet not rebellious—
to nurture all things with ease and submission,
to abandon folly and embrace the unworthy,
without private favor.

The Three Kings governed the world with benevolence.

To apply the six *lü* is to
give life and take it,
to reward and punish,
to bestow and withhold—
this is the Dao/Way.
To subdue chaos and restrain violence,
to elevate the worthy and discard the unworthy,
to correct the crooked and establish the straight,
to clarify the paths of opening and closing,
to ride the times and leverage circumstances,
to serve and govern the hearts of people—
this is the way of the Five Hegemons governing with righteousness.

The Sage who does not embody yin and yang will be overrun;
the king who does not follow the four seasons will be diminished;
the hegemon who does not use the six *lü* will be humiliated;
the ruler who loses the plumb line and square will be deposed.

Thus, the small acting as the great
will reach exhaustion without intimacy;
the great acting as the small
will become narrow and unyielding.

In the age of the Sage-kings,
virtue and the Dao/Way had degrees of excellence;
in the age of the Five Hegemons,
benevolence and righteousness had varying depths.
Great and small could not transgress their bounds.

Laozi said:
*"Though a land be vast and its people numerous,
this is not true strength;
though armor be sturdy and weapons sharp,
this is not reliable victory;
though walls be high and moats deep,
this is not true defense;
though punishments be severe and laws harsh,
this is not true authority."*

chunks.translated_text:
The three cannot be relied upon—only the virtuous/powerful can rule.

For those who preserve governance, though small, they endure;
for those who abandon governance, though great, they perish.

Thus, the skilled in defense need no resistance—*yin* and *yang* suffice.
The skilled in war need no battle—
they ride the times and follow the people’s desires,
and all under Heaven submits.

Therefore, the skilled in governance accumulate virtue/power;
the skilled in wielding arms cultivate forbearance.
When virtue/power is accumulated, the people may be used;
when anger is restrained, authority may be established.

Where the *wen* (cultural refinement) extends deeply,
the *quan* (authoritative measures) command greatly;
where virtue/power is broadly applied,
the authority controls widely—
this is to strengthen oneself while weakening others.

The skilled in wielding arms first weaken the enemy, then engage—
thus, their expenditures are halved while their achievements are tenfold.

A thousand-chariot state practicing *wen* (cultural governance) rules;
a ten-thousand-chariot state fond of war perishes.

The victorious army wins first, then fights;
the defeated army fights first, then seeks victory—
this is ignorance of the Dao/Way.

Lightly wielding arms, though great, will perish;
skillfully employing governance, though small, will flourish.

Preserving the myriad households in the land of no death—this is victory;
driving the people into the land of corpses—this is certain defeat.

*[End of Volume Nine of the Treatise on the Mysterious and True]*

chunks.original_text: 上仁 上德者天下归之，上仁者海内归之，上义者一国归之，上礼者一乡归之。 无此四者，则民不归也。 自《上仁》已下不注篇首，义类此也。 老子曰：君子之道，静以修身，俭以养生。 静即下不扰，下不扰即民不怨； 下扰即政乱，民怨即德薄。 政乱，贤者不为谋； 德薄，勇者不为斗。 明主者，修身以静，养生以俭，上无乱政下无怨民。 则贤自为谋，勇自为斗也。 乱主则不然，一日有天下之富处一主之势，竭百姓之力，以奉耳目之欲。 志专於宫室台榭、沟池苑囿、猛兽珍怪。 贫民饥饿，虎狼厌刍豢，百姓冻寒，宫室衣锜绣。 故人主畜兹无用之物，而天下不安其姓命矣。 此暗主居一日之位，极一主之势，殚天下之财，毒流四海，竭万民之产，恣心目所娱，若秦主之二世，用之则昏也。 老子曰：非淡漠无以明德，非宁静无以致远，非宽大无以并覆，非正平无以制断。 以天下之目视，以天下之耳听，以天下之心虑，以天下之力争，故号令能下究，而臣情得上闻，百官修达#1，群臣辐凑。 喜不以赏赐，怒不以罪诛。 法令察而不苛，耳目聪#2而不暗，善否之情，日陈於前而不逆。 故贤者尽其智，不肖者竭其力，近者安其性，远者怀其德，得用人之道也。 此明君治国如此，用人如彼，若汉之孝文，唐之太宗也。 夫乘舆马者，不劳而致千里； 乘舟楫者，不游而济江海。 使言之而是，虽商夫刍荛，犹不可弃也； 言之而非，虽在人君卿相，犹不可用也。 是非之处，不可以贵贱尊卑论也。 其计可用，不羞其位； 其言可行，不贵其辩。 夫用得其道，不劳而至，不行而达。 故轩皇感牧童之言而天下理，有贱乎卑弱邪？ 胡亥信赵高之谋而天下亡，有贵乎卿佐也？ 暗主则不然，群臣尽诚效忠者希，不用其身也。 而亲习邪枉，贤者不能见也； 疏远卑贱，竭力尽忠者不能闻也。 有言者，穷之以辞； 有谏者，诛之以罪。
chunks.translated_text:
The benevolent sovereign of **upper virtue** and the virtuous/powerful sovereign of **upper Dao** will have all under heaven flock to him;
the sovereign of **upper virtue** will have all within the seas come to him;
the sovereign of **upper righteousness** will have one state unite under him;
the sovereign of **upper propriety** will have one village follow him.
Without these four, the people will not flock to him.
From *"Upper Virtue"* onward, no chapter annotations are given—its meaning is similar.

The *Laozi* says:
The **Dao/Way** of the gentleman is to cultivate stillness to refine oneself,
to practice frugality to nourish life.
Stillness means not disturbing below—
if below is not disturbed, the people will not grumble;
if below is disturbed, governance will falter—
the people grumble when virtue/power is thin.
When governance falters, the wise do not offer counsel;
when virtue/power is thin, the brave do not fight.
The enlightened sovereign cultivates stillness to refine himself,
practices frugality to nourish life,
so that above there is no chaotic governance and below there are no grumbling people.
Then the wise offer counsel of their own accord,
and the brave fight for their own sake.
The chaotic sovereign is not thus:
In one day, he may possess the wealth of all under heaven,
command the power of one sovereign,
exhaust the people’s strength to gratify his senses,
while his ambitions fix on palaces and pavilions,
moats and ponds, gardens and enclosures,
tigers and rare beasts.
The poor suffer hunger and cold,
while the halls are decked in embroidered silks.
Thus, though the sovereign hoards these useless things,
the world does not rest beneath his rule.
This is the dark sovereign in his single day of power,
extorting the wealth of the world,
poisoning the four seas,
exhausting the people’s livelihoods,
indulging his eyes and ears in pleasure—
like the Second Emperor of Qin, whose use of power led only to folly.

The *Laozi* says:
Without simplicity, one cannot clarify virtue/power;
without tranquility, one cannot attain the distant;
without magnanimity, one cannot embrace and cover all;
without fairness, one cannot make decisive judgments.
To see with the eyes of all under heaven,
to hear with the ears of all under heaven,
to deliberate with the hearts of all under heaven,
to contend with the strength of all under heaven—
thus, his commands reach their full extent,
and the sentiments of his ministers ascend to his ears.
Officials diligently perform their duties,
while ministers gather like spokes to the hub.
He does not reward for joy,
nor punish for anger.
His laws are discerning yet not harsh;
his senses are keen yet not obscured.
The truth and falsehood of matters are laid bare before him daily,
and he does not resist them.
Thus, the wise exhaust their intelligence,
the unworthy strain their strength,
the near feel secure in their nature,
the distant cherish his virtue/power—
this is the **Dao/Way** of employing people.
Such is how the enlightened sovereign governs his state,
and how he employs his people—
like the Han’s Emperor Gaozu or the Tang’s Emperor Taizong.

He who rides in the imperial carriage and on fine horses
travels a thousand *li* without labor;
he who sails on ships and steers oars
crosses rivers and seas without swimming.
If one’s words are true, though he be a merchant or a humble laborer,
he should not be discarded;
if one’s words are false, though he be a sovereign, minister, or high official,
he should not be employed.
The judgment of truth and falsehood
cannot be decided by rank or status.
If one’s plans are useful, he need not be ashamed of his station;
if one’s words are practical, he need not be prized for his eloquence.
When employing people in accord with the **Dao/Way**,
one achieves results without effort,
and reaches understanding without action.
Thus, the Yellow Emperor was moved by the words of a shepherd boy
and brought order to all under heaven—
was he truly of low and weak status?
Hu Hai trusted the schemes of Zhao Gao
and lost all under heaven—
was Zhao Gao truly of noble rank?
The dark sovereign is not thus:
Few ministers offer sincere loyalty,
for he does not employ their talents.
He favors those close and familiar with deceit,
so the wise cannot be seen;
he spurns those distant, humble, and lowly,
so those who strain their strength and offer loyal counsel cannot be heard.
If one speaks, he exhausts them with words;
if one remonstrates, he executes them with charges.

chunks.original_text: 如此而欲安海内，存万方，其离聪明亦以远矣。 非圣不能静四海，非明无以安万方。 老子曰：能尊生，虽富贵不以养伤身，虽贫贱不以利累形。 虽日费万金不恣口以害生，虽家无儋石不苟求以伤德，可谓能尊生矣。 今受先祖之遗爵，必重失之； 生之所由来久矣，而轻失之，岂不惑哉。 贵以身治天下，可以寄天下； 爱以身治天下，所以托天下。 承先人遗业而失之者，必由轻失。 故不责於己，无以托天下也。 文子问治国之本，老子曰：本在於治身。 未尝闻身治而国乱者也，身乱而国治者未有也。 故曰：修之身，其德乃真。 身苟未治，而况国哉？ 道之所以至妙者，父不能以教子，子亦不能受之於父。 故道可道，非常道也； 名可名，非常名也。 常道无名，可名非道。 故言论之所不及，父子莫能相传也。 文子问曰：何行而民亲其上。 老子曰：使之以时，而敬慎之，如临深渊，如履薄冰。 天地之间，善即吾畜也，不善即吾雠也。 昔者夏商之臣，反雠桀纣而臣汤武； 宿沙之民，自攻其君，归神农氏。 故曰：人之所畏，不可不畏也。 可畏非君，可畏非善。 老子曰：治大者，道不可以小，地广者，制不可以狭； 位高者，事不可以烦； 民众者，教不可以苛。 事烦难治，法苛难行，求多难赡。 寸而度之，至丈必差； 铢而称之，至石必过。 石称丈量，径而寡失。 大较易为智，曲辩难为慧。 道隐小成，言隐浮伪。 故无益於治，有益於乱者，圣人不为也； 无益於用者，有益於费者，智者不行也。 故功不厌约，事不厌省，求不厌寡。 功约易成，事省易治，求寡易赡，任於众人则易。 故小辩害义，小义破道，道小必不通，通必简。 圣人通明，洞见未然，不以小蔽大，不以烦易简也。 河以逶迤故能远，非一勺之水也。 山以陵迟故能高，非一匊之土也。 道以优游故能化。 非即时所致也。 夫通於一伎，审於一事，察於一能，可以曲说，不可以广应也。 夫调音者，小弦急，大弦缓； 立事者，贱者劳，贵者佚。 言匀弦大小适中，治国者贵贱皆当也。 道之言曰，芒芒昧昧，因天之威，与天同炁。 同炁者帝，同义者王，同功者霸，无一焉者亡。 同炁者无德而称，同义者救时之危，同功者与民同利。 无一於此，以至危亡也。 故不言而信，不施而仁，不怒而威，是以天心动化者也。 五帝自然无为，与天同心，物禀其生，感而化也。 施而仁，言而信，怒而威，是以精诚为之者也。 三王精诚发内，动应於外，而犹有迹，未同於无心也。 施而不仁，言而不信，怒而不威，是以外貌为之者也。 五霸诚不由中，物无应者，故虽怒而不威。 故有道以理之，法虽少，足以治； 无道以理之，法虽众，足以乱。 治存道要，乱存法多。 老子曰：鲸鱼失水，则制於蝼蚁； 人君舍其所守，而与臣争事，则制於有司。 鱼不可失水，君不可亡道。 以无为持位，守职者以听从取容，臣下藏智而不用，反以事专其上。 人君者不任能而好自为，则智日困而自负责。 数穷於下，则不能申理； 行堕於位，则不能持制。 智不足以为治，威不足以行刑，则无以与下#3交矣。 喜怒形於心，嗜欲见於外，则守职者离正而阿上，有司枉法而从风。 赏不当功，诛不应罪，则上下乖心，君臣相怨。
chunks.translated_text:
「Thus yet seeking to bring peace to all under heaven,
to preserve the myriad lands,
his distance from wisdom and sagacity is already vast.

Without **saintly** virtue, one cannot still the four seas;
without **sagacity**, one cannot bring peace to the myriad lands.

**Laozi** said:
*"He who can honor life,
though rich and noble does not harm his body with sustenance,
though poor and humble does not burden his form with gain.
Though he spends ten thousand gold daily,
he does not indulge his mouth to harm life;
though his home lacks even a single grain,
he does not begrudgingly seek to injure **virtue/power**.
This may be called honoring life indeed.*

Now, receiving the hereditary noble rank of one’s ancestors,
one must surely place great weight on not losing it—
yet life’s origin has endured for ages,
and to lightly risk losing it, is this not perplexing?

To govern the world with noble rank is to entrust it with the world;
to govern the world with love is to rely upon it with the world.

Those who inherit the legacy of their ancestors yet lose it,
must surely do so through careless neglect.

Thus, if one does not blame oneself,
there is no way to entrust the world with oneself.

**Wenzzi** asked about the foundation of ruling a state,
and **Laozi** replied:
*"The foundation lies in governing oneself.
Never have I heard of a state in disorder while the self is governed,
nor has there ever been a state in order while the self is disordered.
Hence it is said:
Refine oneself, and one’s **virtue/power** shall be true.
If one’s self is not yet governed, how much less the state?"*

The **Dao/Way** is so supremely wondrous,
that a father cannot teach it to his son,
nor can a son receive it from his father.
Thus, the **Dao/Way** that can be spoken of is not the constant **Dao/Way**;
the name that can be named is not the constant name.
The constant **Dao/Way** has no name—
what can be named is not the **Dao/Way**.
Hence, what words and discourse cannot encompass,
fathers and sons cannot pass it on.

**Wenzzi** asked:
*"What conduct ensures the people love their ruler?"*
**Laozi** replied:
*"Lead them with proper timing,
and treat them with reverence and caution,
as though standing at the edge of a deep abyss,
or walking on thin ice.
Between heaven and earth,
the good become my nurtured subjects,
the unworthy become my **enemies**.
In ancient times, the ministers of Xia and Shang,
avenged the wrongs of Jie and Zhou
and served as subjects to Tang and Wu.
The people of Huosha,
attacked their own lord
and joined the followers of **Shennong**.*

Hence it is said:
*"What the people fear,
one must not fail to fear.
What is truly fearsome is not the ruler,
what is truly fearsome is not mere goodness."*

**Laozi** said:
*"To govern the great,
the **Dao/Way** cannot be trifling;
to rule vast lands,
the measures cannot be narrow;
to occupy high station,
the duties cannot be burdensome;
to lead many people,
the teachings cannot be harsh.
Burdensome duties are hard to govern,
harsh laws are hard to implement,
demands that are excessive are hard to satisfy.
Measure an inch with a ruler,
and by a yard it will surely be off;
weigh a **qian** with a balance,
and by a **dan** it will surely be excessive.
Yet weigh with a balance and measure with a ruler,
and even by a **dan** or a yard,
the errors will be few.
It is easy to be wise in broad strokes,
but subtle reasoning is hard to make sagacious.
The **Dao/Way** lies hidden in small things yet achieves greatness,
words lie hidden in simplicity yet reveal superficiality.
Thus, what does not benefit governance
but instead harms it,
the **saintly** does not practice;
what does not benefit utility
but instead wastes it,
the wise do not employ.

Hence, deeds are not to be scorned for being too restrained,
tasks are not to be scorned for being too few,
demands are not to be scorned for being too sparse.
Restrained deeds are easy to accomplish,
few tasks are easy to govern,
sparse demands are easy to satisfy,
and entrusting matters to the people makes it easy.
Thus, petty reasoning harms **righteousness**,
petty **righteousness** breaks the **Dao/Way**,
and the **Dao/Way** must be simple to be comprehensive.
The **saintly** are comprehensive in wisdom,
perceiving what has not yet come to pass,
not allowing small things to obscure the great,
nor burdensome matters to replace simplicity.

The river flows far because of its winding course,
not because it is a single ladle of water.
The mountain rises high because of its gradual ascent,
not because it is a single handful of soil.
The **Dao/Way** transforms because of its ease and flow,
not because of what is achieved in an instant.

He who excels in one skill,
is meticulous in one matter,
and discerning in one ability,
can employ clever arguments,
but cannot broadly apply them.

The tuner of music,
tightens the small strings,
and loosens the large ones;
the establisher of affairs,
makes the lowly labor,
and lets the noble rest.
Words say:
*"Balance the strings, fit the large and small—
in governing a state, noble and lowly alike must be justly treated."*

The words of the **Dao/Way** say:
*"Vague and indistinct,
align with heaven’s might,
and harmonize with heaven’s **qi**.
He who harmonizes with **qi** becomes **Emperor**,
he who harmonizes with **righteousness** becomes **King**,
he who harmonizes with deeds becomes **Hegemon**.
He who lacks all three perishes.
He who harmonizes with **qi** is without **virtue/power** yet is called so;
he who harmonizes with **righteousness** rescues the peril of the age;
he who harmonizes with deeds shares benefits with the people.
Without one of these three,
the peril of ruin is inevitable.
Hence, one does not speak yet is believed,
does not act yet is benevolent,
does not rage yet is awe-inspiring—
thus, the **heavenly heart** moves and transforms.

The Five **Emperors** acted naturally without effort,
harmonizing with heaven’s will.
All things received their life from them,
and responded in transformation.

To act yet be benevolent,
to speak yet be trustworthy,
to rage yet be awe-inspiring—
this is what is achieved through **sincerity** and **inner power**.

The Three **Kings**’ **sincerity** and **inner power** emanated from within,
responding outwardly in action,
yet still left traces,
not yet fully harmonized with the **heartless**.

To act yet lack benevolence,
to speak yet lack trustworthiness,
to rage yet lack awe—
this is what is achieved through mere outward appearance.

The Five **Hegemons**’ **sincerity** did not arise from the heart,
and thus nothing responded to them.
Hence, though they raged, they were not awe-inspiring.

Thus, with the **Dao/Way** to guide them,
even few laws suffice for governance;
without the **Dao/Way** to guide them,
even many laws suffice only for chaos.
Governance depends on the **Dao/Way** being essential,
chaos depends on laws being excessive.

**Laozi** said:
*"A whalefish out of water is controlled by ants;
a ruler who abandons his **Dao/Way**
and disputes matters with his ministers,
is controlled by his officials.
Fish cannot be out of water,
nor can a ruler abandon the **Dao/Way**.
To uphold one’s station with **non-action**,
those who guard their duties take refuge in obedience,
while ministers conceal their wisdom and do not act—
instead, they allow their superiors to monopolize affairs.
A ruler who does not entrust capable ministers
but prefers to act himself,
shall find his wisdom daily constrained
while he bears the blame alone.
If justice is exhausted below,
he cannot extend proper governance;
if his conduct falters in his station,
he cannot maintain authority.
If wisdom is insufficient for governance,
and awe is insufficient to enforce punishment,
then there is no way to interact with his subjects.

If joy and anger manifest in the heart,
and desires appear outwardly,
then those who guard their duties
shall abandon principle to curry favor,
and officials shall pervert the law to follow the wind.
If rewards do not match deeds,
and punishments do not fit crimes,
then ruler and subjects shall be at odds,
and sovereign and ministers shall harbor mutual resentment.»

chunks.original_text: 百官烦乱，而智不能解； 非誉萌生，而明不能照。 非己之失，而反自责，则人主愈劳，人臣愈佚。 是代大匠斲，夫代大匠斲者，希有不伤其手矣。 人主任贤举能，不专断於己。 则智有所因，明有不照，则守职阿上，有司正法。 故无辜受戮，有功者不偿，主愈劳，臣愈佚。 是代大匠斲，坐伤其手也。 与马逐走，筋绝不能及也，上车摄辔，马死衡下。 伯乐相之，王良御之，明主乘之，无御相之劳，而致千里，善乘人之资也。 夫人主居上以御群下，所任忠正，不必形神。 其由乘马，假在相御，可坐致千里，不为难也。 人君之道，无为而有就也，有立而无好也。 有为即议，有好即谀； 议即可夺，谀即可诱。 诱其私好，夺其正术。 夫以建而制於人者，不能持国。 故善建者不拔，言建之无形也。 唯神化者，物莫能胜。 夫为上者，常能制人，不为人所制。 不为人所制者，是善建者不拔。 用之无形，故曰神化。 中欲不出，谓之扃； 外邪不入，谓之闭。 中扃外闭，何事不节？ 外闭中扃，何事不成？ 中扃外闭，无欲无害。 故不用之、不为之，而有用之、而有为之。 有用即为之，未有为而不用也。 不伐之言，不夺之事，循名责实，使自有司，以不知为道，以禁苛为主，如此则百官之事，各有所考。 君存大体，任於百官，详其考校，定其得失而已。 老子曰：食者，民之本也； 民者，国之基也。 故人君者，上因天时，下尽地理，中用人力。 是以群生以#4。 长，万物蕃殖。 春伐枯槁，夏收百果，秋蓄蔬食，冬取薪蒸#5。 以为民资，生无乏用，死无传丁恋切。 尸君能保和，死生尽理。 先王之法，不掩群而取镺，上袄下滔。 不涸泽而渔，不焚林而猎。 不极物也。 豺未祭兽，罝罘音浮。 不得通於野； 獭未祭鱼，网罟不得入於水； 鹰隼未击，罗网不得张於皋； 草木未落，斤斧不得入於山林； 昆虫未垫，不得以火田； 育孕不杀，鷇音遘。 卵不探； 鱼不长尺不得取，犬豕不期音饥。 年不得食。 皆以其时，不妄害也。 是故万物之发生，若蒸炁出。 谓杀非其时，取非其当，则万物精炁发动上达于天，将害於人也。 先王之所以应时修备、富国利民之道也。 养之有宜，取之以时，不乖其道，所以富国宁家。 非目见而足行之也，欲利民不忌乎心，则民自备矣。 以心揆物，以身观人，何假扬眉举足，然后方备？ 老子曰：古者明君，取下有节，自养有度，必计岁而收，量民积聚，知有余不足之数，然后取奉。 如此即得承所受於天地，而离於饥寒之患。 其憯怛於民也，国有饥者，食不重味； 民有寒者，冬不被裘； 与民同苦乐，即天下无哀民此明君之治天下也如此。 暗主即不然，取民，不裁其力； 求下，不量其积，男女不得耕织之业以供上求。 力勤财尽，有旦无暮，君臣相疾。 且人之为生也，一人跖音只。 禾而耕不益十亩，中田之收，不过四石，妻子老弱，仰之而食。 或时有灾害之患，无以供上求。 即人主愍之矣，贪主暴君，涸渔其下，以适无极之欲，则百姓不被天和，履地德矣。 此暗主之治天下也如彼。 老子曰：天地之炁，莫大於和。 和者，阴阳调，日夜分。 故万物春分而生，秋分而成，生与成必得和之精。 故积阴不生，积阳不化，阴阳交接，乃能成和。
chunks.translated_text:
The myriad officials grow chaotic, yet wisdom cannot disentangle them;
Praise does not arise, yet sagacity cannot illuminate it.
Not one’s own fault, yet he blames himself alone—
Then the sovereign’s labors increase, while ministers grow more negligent.

This is like the artisan who carves in place of the master.
He who carves in place of the master,
Rarely fails to harm his own hands.

When the sovereign entrusts the worthy and selects the capable,
And does not monopolize decisions for himself,
Then wisdom has its source, and sagacity need not always shine—
The guardians of duty shall not flatter above,
And the ministers shall uphold the law.
Yet still the innocent are slain,
And those with merit are not rewarded—
The sovereign’s labors increase, while ministers grow more negligent.

This is like the artisan who carves in place of the master,
And sits, harming his own hands.

To chase horses with their swiftness,
One’s sinews shall snap and fail to keep up—
To seize the reins from the chariot,
The horse shall die beneath the yoke.

The **Bólé** discerns them, the **Wángliáng** drives them,
A wise sovereign rides them—
Without the effort of discernment or driving,
Yet reaches a thousand *lǐ*—
This is the art of leveraging others’ strengths.

The sovereign, seated above, governs the multitude below;
His trust lies in loyalty and rectitude,
Not in outward form or inner spirit.
As with riding a horse,
He relies on the **shì** [discerning official] and the **yù** [driver],
Achieving a thousand *lǐ* without exertion—
This is no hardship.

The **Way** of the sovereign:
To act without attachment, to establish without preference.
To act is to debate,
To prefer is to flatter—
Debate invites usurpation,
Flattery invites corruption.
Corrupting his private inclinations,
Usurping his rightful governance—
He who submits to others’ control,
Cannot sustain the realm.

Thus, the master of governance does not pluck [at will];
This is because governance is formless.
Only those who embody **shénhuà** [transformation of the spirit],
No force can overcome.

The sovereign who governs,
Ever controls others—
Never controlled by others—
This is the master of governance who does not pluck [at will].
To use without visible form,
Hence the term **shénhuà**.

When inner desires do not manifest,
This is called **"jīng"** [restraining];
When outer evils do not enter,
This is called **"bì"** [closing].
To restrain within and close without,
What matter cannot be moderated?
To close without and restrain within,
What task cannot be accomplished?
To restrain within and close without,
There are no desires, no harms.

Thus, he does not act for them,
Nor does he act against them—
Yet they act for him,
And he acts through them.
Words that are not refuted,
Deeds that are not thwarted—
Following names to assess reality,
Letting each minister bear responsibility—
To regard ignorance as the **Way**,
To forbid cruelty as the sovereign’s principle—
Then the myriad officials’ affairs,
Each shall find their proper measure.

The sovereign preserves the grand framework,
Entrusts it to the myriad officials,
Examines their deliberations,
And determines their merits and faults—
That is all.

**Lǎozǐ** said:
*"The nourished are the people’s foundation;
The people are the realm’s base.
Thus the sovereign,
Above, follows the **Dao** of Heaven and its seasons,
Below, exhausts the logic of Earth,
Within, employs the strength of the people.
Hence the myriad creatures thrive—
Growth and abundance flourish.
Spring, he prunes the withered;
Summer, he harvests the fruits;
Autumn, he stores the vegetables and grains;
Winter, he gathers firewood and salt.
As the people’s resources,
They lack nothing in life,
And in death, no orphaned descendants mourn.
The corpse of the sovereign can preserve harmony,
Life and death are both in order."*

The **Way** of the ancient kings:
Does not net the multitude while seeking the **máo** [wild boar],
Nor flood the marshes while hunting fish.
Does not net the multitude while seeking the **máo** [wild boar],
Nor flood the marshes while hunting fish.
Does not exhaust the creatures.

The **yáo** [wolf] has not yet been sacrificed,
Yet the **zhì** [noose] resounds with empty sounds—
It cannot reach the wilds;
The **tǎ** [otter] has not yet been sacrificed,
Yet the nets do not enter the waters—
The **yīng** [eagle] and **sǔn** [hawk] have not yet struck,
Yet the snares are not spread upon the **gāo** [highlands];
The grasses and trees have not yet fallen,
Yet the axes and blades do not enter the forests—
The insects have not yet been roasted,
Nor the pregnant slain—
The **zhèn** [nest] is not yet explored,
The fish not yet grown to a *chǐ* [foot] in length are taken,
Nor the dogs and swine allowed to starve—
The year’s harvest is not yet ripe.

All follow their proper time,
And do not recklessly harm.

Thus, the myriad creatures’ births,
Like the **zhēng** [breath] of **yīn-yáng** [yin-yang],
Are said to rise when their **jīng-qì** [vital essence] is slain,
And their **dào** [proper measure] is taken—
Then the myriad creatures’ vital essence and **qì** surge upward,
Reaching the heavens,
And shall bring harm to mankind.

This is the **Way** of the ancient kings
To respond to the seasons in preparation,
To enrich the realm and benefit the people.

To nourish with propriety,
To take in due measure—
Not to disrupt their **Way**—
This is how the realm is enriched,
And the family preserved.

It is not a matter of what the eyes see
And the feet can reach—
If he desires to benefit the people,
And does not harbor resentment in his heart,
Then the people shall naturally provide.

To measure things by the heart,
To observe others by the body—
What need to raise brows or move feet,
Before all is complete?

**Lǎozǐ** said:
*"The ancient sovereigns,
When taking from below, had moderation;
When nourishing themselves, had restraint.
They calculated the year’s harvest,
Measured the people’s stored wealth,
Knew the surplus and the deficit—
Then they took and offered.
Thus they received what Heaven and Earth bestowed,
And avoided the perils of hunger and cold.
Their grief for the people was profound—
When the realm had famine,
Their food lacked savor;
When the people were cold,
Their winter cloaks were not fur-lined—
Sharing the people’s joys and sorrows,
Thus the world had no grieving subjects—
This was the ancient sovereign’s governance of the realm."*

The **dark sovereign** is not so.
When taking from the people,
He does not limit their strength;
When demanding from below,
He does not measure their stores—
Men and women cannot till and weave
To meet his endless demands.
Their labor is exhausted, their wealth depleted—
They have no dawn without dusk,
And sovereign and ministers alike grow weary.

Moreover, when a man plows,
One *zhǐ* [fathom] of grain does not benefit ten *mǔ* [mu] of land—
The yield of average fields,
Does not exceed four *dàn* [bushels].
His aged wife, children, and infirm dependents,
Rely on him for sustenance.
If calamity or disaster strikes,
They cannot meet the sovereign’s demands.
Then the sovereign pities them—
But the greedy tyrant,
Draining the people like a fisherman in drought,
To satisfy his insatiable desires—
Then the common folk do not enjoy Heaven’s harmony,
Nor walk upon Earth’s **virtue** [de].

This is the **dark sovereign’s** governance of the realm.

**Lǎozǐ** said:
*"The **qì** of Heaven and Earth,
None greater than **harmony**.
**Harmony** is the balance of **yīn-yáng** [yin-yang],
The division of day and night.
Thus, when spring arrives, all things are born,
When autumn comes, all things mature—
Birth and maturity must draw from **harmony’s** essence.
Hence, accumulated **yīn** does not give life,
Accumulated **yáng** does not transform—
Only when **yīn-yáng** intermingle,
Does **harmony** arise."*

chunks.original_text: 此天地之气和平，故万物得以生成。 是以圣人之道，宽而栗，严而温，柔而直，猛而仁。 夫太刚则折，太柔则卷，道正在於刚柔之间。 夫绳之为度也，可卷而怀也，引而申之，可直而布也。 长而不横，短而不穷，直而不刚，故圣人体之。 此圣人之和也。 柔而能直，良匠之规矩也，卷而能舒，圣人之法度也。 夫恩推即懦，懦即不威； 严推即猛，猛即不和； 爱推即纵，纵即不令，刑推即祸，祸即无亲； 是以贵和也。 老子曰：国之所以存者，得道也； 所以亡者，理塞也。 故圣人见化以观其征。 德有昌衰，风为先萌。 故得生道者，虽小必大； 有亡征者，虽成必败。 国之亡也，大不足恃； 道之行也，小不可轻。 故存在得道，不在於小； 亡在失道，不在於大。 故乱国之主，务於地广，而不务於仁义； 务在高位，而不务於道德。 是舍其所以存，造音操。 其所以亡也。 观贤愚以取兴亡，存道德不在其广大也。 若上乱三光之明下失万民之心孰不能承？ 故审其己者，不备诸人也。 古之为君#6者，深行之谓之道德，浅行之谓之仁义，薄行之谓之礼智。 此六者，国家之纲维也。 深行之则厚得福； 浅行之则薄得福； 尽行之天下服。 古者修道德即正天下，修仁义即正一国，修礼智即正一乡。 德厚者大，德薄者小，故道不以雄武立，不以坚强胜，不以贪竞得。 立在天下推己，胜在天下自服，得在天下与之，不在於自取。 故雌牝即立，柔弱即胜，仁义即得，不争即莫能与之争。 故道之在於天下也，譬犹江海也。 天之道，为者败之，执者失之。 失欲名之大，而求之争之，吾见其不得已。 而虽执而得之，不留也。 夫名不可求而得也，在天下与之。 与之者归之。 天下所归者，德也。 故云：上德者天下归之，上仁者海内归之，上义者一国归之，上礼者一乡归之。 无此四者，民不归也。 不归用兵，即危道也。 故曰：兵者，不祥之器，不得已而用之，杀伤人胜而勿美。 故曰：死地，荆棘生焉，以悲哀泣之，以丧礼居之。 是以君子务於道德，不重用兵也。 行之有浅深，而德之有厚薄。 道德不可暂亡，凶器不宜妄动。 文子问：仁义礼何以为薄於道德也？ 老子曰：为仁者，必以哀乐论之； 为义者，必以取与明之。 四海之内，哀乐不能遍，竭府库之财货，不足以赡万民。 言恩惠不能普。 故知不如修道而行德，因天地之性，万物自正，而天下赡，仁义因附。 是以大丈夫居其厚，不居其薄。 故知道德深厚而仁义浅薄，故圣人居其厚，不处其薄也。 夫礼者，实之文也； 仁者，恩之效也。 故礼因人情而制，不过其实； 仁不溢恩，悲哀抱於情，送死称於仁。 夫养生，不强人所不能及，不绝人所不能已，度量不失其适，非誉无由生矣。 故制乐足以合欢，不出於和，明於死生之分，通於侈俭之适也。 人情失和，故兴於仁义，节以礼乐，各使明其分而不相逾。 末世即不然，言与行相悖，情与貌相反，礼饰以烦，乐扰以淫，风俗溺於世，非誉萃於朝，故至人废而不用也。 未世谓乐淫、变节、礼烦、饰情，至人见其如此，故执其朴素，易其风俗。 与骥逐走，即人不胜骥； 托於车上，即骥不胜人。

This is the **harmony** of Heaven and Earth’s **qì**,
Thus all things attain birth and maturity.

Therefore, the **Dao** of the Sage
Is broad yet cautious,
Stern yet warm,
Soft yet upright,
Fierce yet benevolent.

Excessive rigidity breaks,
Excessive softness curls inward—
The **Dao** lies between **just** and **yielding**.

Like a measuring line,
It can be rolled and held,
Stretched and laid straight—
Long yet not sprawling,
Short yet not confined,
Straight yet not rigid—
Thus the Sage embodies it.

This is the Sage’s **harmony**.

Soft yet able to stand firm—
The carpenter’s square and compass.
Coiled yet able to unfold—
The Sage’s laws and measures.

Push benevolence too far, it becomes weakness—
Weakness lacks authority.
Push sternness too far, it becomes brutality—
Brutality lacks **harmony**.
Push love too far, it becomes indulgence—
Indulgence lacks order.
Push punishment too far, it becomes calamity—
Calamity breeds estrangement.
Thus, **harmony** is most valued.

**Lǎozǐ** said:
*"A realm endures by attaining the **Dao**;
It perishes by obstruction of principle.
Thus the Sage observes transformations to discern their omens.
**Virtue** waxes or wanes—
The winds first stir its signs.
Those who grasp the **Dao** of life,
Though small, shall grow great;
Those who bear signs of ruin,
Though established, shall fall.
A realm’s ruin does not lie in vastness;
The **Dao**’s practice cannot be slighted.
Thus survival lies in attaining the **Dao**,
Not in size;
Ruination lies in losing the **Dao**,
Not in grandeur.
Rulers of chaotic realms
Seek only broad lands,
Yet neglect **virtue** and **righteousness**;
Strive for high stations,
Yet neglect **Dao** and **moral power**.
They abandon what sustains them,
And court their own destruction.

The wise observe the wise and foolish
To judge the rise and fall of states—
**Virtue** and **moral power** endure,
Not in their scale, but in their depth.
If the sovereign above disrupts the **Three Lights**’ radiance,
And loses the people’s hearts below—
Who cannot fail to crumble?

Thus those who scrutinize themselves
Need not fear others.

In ancient times,
Deep practice was called **Dao** and **virtue**,
Shallow practice, **righteousness** and **benevolence**,
Thin practice, **rites** and **wisdom**.
These six are the state’s vital threads.
Deep practice brings thick blessings;
Shallow practice, thin blessings;
Full practice—all under Heaven submits.
In antiquity,
Cultivating **Dao** and **virtue** rectified all under Heaven,
Cultivating **righteousness** and **benevolence** rectified a realm,
Cultivating **rites** and **wisdom** rectified a village.
Thick **virtue** brings greatness,
Thin **virtue** brings smallness—
Thus the **Dao** does not rely on martial prowess,
Nor on strength or greed to prevail,
Nor on competition to gain.
To stand in all under Heaven is to push oneself outward,
To prevail is to let all under Heaven submit of its own accord,
To gain is to give to all under Heaven—
Not to seize for oneself.
Thus the yielding attains firmness,
The weak attain victory,
**Righteousness** and **benevolence** attain success,
The non-contentious cannot be contended with.
Thus the **Dao** in all under Heaven
Is like the great rivers and seas.

Heaven’s **Dao**:
Those who act against it perish,
Those who grasp it lose it.
To covet great fame while striving for it—
I see it as inevitable failure.
Yet even if grasped, it does not remain.
Great fame cannot be seized—
It is given by all under Heaven.
To give is to receive.
All under Heaven’s allegiance is to **virtue**.
Thus it is said:
The **virtue** of the highest **Dao** draws all under Heaven,
The **benevolence** of the highest **Dao** draws all within the seas,
The **righteousness** of the highest **Dao** draws a realm,
The **rites** of the highest **Dao** draw a village.
Without these four, the people will not submit.
If they do not submit, arms are used—
This is the perilous **Dao**.

Thus it is said:
*"Weapons are the most ominous tools.
Used only when unavoidable,
Victory brings no joy in slaughter.
Thus it is said:
In the land of death, thorns and brambles grow—
Mournful weeping fills the air,
Funeral rites mark the dwellings.
Therefore the **Junzi** prioritizes **Dao** and **virtue**,
And rarely resorts to arms.
Practice varies in depth,
**Virtue** in thickness—
**Dao** and **virtue** cannot be momentarily abandoned,
Warlike tools should not be recklessly wielded."*

**Wénzǐ** asked:
*"Why are **righteousness**, **benevolence**, and **rites** inferior to **Dao** and **virtue**?"*

**Lǎozǐ** said:
*"Those who practice **benevolence** must weigh it by sorrow and joy;
Those who practice **righteousness** must clarify giving and taking.
Within the Four Seas, sorrow and joy cannot reach all,
And exhausting the treasury’s wealth cannot suffice for the people.
Thus kindness cannot be universal.
Therefore, it is better to cultivate the **Dao** and practice **virtue**,
Aligning with Heaven and Earth’s nature—
All things then self-regulate,
And all under Heaven is nourished,
While **righteousness** and **benevolence** follow naturally.

Thus the **true man** dwells in the thick,
Not the thin.
Knowing the **Dao**’s **virtue** is profound while **righteousness** is shallow,
The Sage abides in the thick,
Not the thin.

**Rites** are the adornment of substance;
**Benevolence** is the manifestation of kindness.
Thus **rites** follow human nature without excess,
**Benevolence** does not overflow kindness—
Mourning the dead aligns with **benevolence**,
Funeral rites fulfill **rites**.
Nurturing life does not force what cannot be borne,
Nor sever what cannot be abandoned—
Measure and moderation never stray from balance,
And unearned praise finds no root.

Thus music suffices to unite joy,
Yet never strays from **harmony**,
Clarifying the division of life and death,
And the balance of extravagance and frugality.
When human nature loses **harmony**,
**Righteousness** and **benevolence** arise,
Regulated by **rites** and music,
Each made clear in their place without overstepping.

In the later ages, it is not so—
Words and deeds contradict,
Emotions and appearances clash,
**Rites** become burdensome adornments,
Music turns to licentious chaos,
Customs drown in worldly excess,
Praise and blame converge in court,
Thus the **true man** is abandoned and unused.

The later age is marked by:
Music’s licentiousness,
**Rites**’ corruption,
**Rites** becoming burdensome,
Emotions masked in pretense—
When the **true man** sees this,
He embraces simplicity,
Transforming customs.
If he races with the swift horse on foot,
Man cannot outpace the horse;
But mounted in a chariot,
The horse cannot outpace man."*

None greater than **harmony**.
**Harmony** is the balance of **yīn-yáng** [yin-yang],
The division of day and night.
Thus, when spring arrives, all things are born,
When autumn comes, all things mature—
Birth and maturity must draw from **harmony’s** essence.
Hence, accumulated **yīn** does not give life,
Accumulated **yáng** does not transform—
Only when **yīn-yáng** intermingle,
Does **harmony** arise."*

chunks.original_text: 故善用道者，乘人之资以立功，以其所能托其所不能也。 主与之以时，民报之以财； 主遇之以礼，民报之以死。 故有危国，无安君； 有忧主，无乐臣。 德过其位者，尊； 禄过其德者，凶。 德贵无高，义取无多。 不以德贵者，窃位也； 不以义取者，盗财也。 无德而贵者凶，非义而取者盗。 圣人安贫乐道，不以欲伤生，不以利累己，故不违义而妄取古#7。 者无德，不尊； 无能，不官； 无功，不赏； 无罪，不诛。 其进人也，以礼； 其退人也，以义。 小人之世，其进人也，若上之天； 其退人也，若内之渊。 圣人之用人也，不苟进，不安退； 小人则用之恐不高，退之恨不深也。 言古者，以疾今也。 敏今时偷薄，好之欲其生，恶之欲其死也。 相马，失之瘦； 选士，失之贫。 豚肥充厨，骨音寺。 不官。 马在良，虽瘦，可以致远； 臣在忠，虽贫，可以成事。 君子察实，无信谗言。 君过而不谏，非忠臣也； 谏而不听，君不明也。 不谏者谓尸禄也，不听者暴主也。 民沉溺而不忧，非贤君也。 故守节死难，人臣之职也； 衣寒食饥，慈父之恩也。 有君如此，何虑社稷之危亡，有臣如此？ 何忧爵禄之不备？

The **Dao/Way** is well-used when:

One rides upon the people’s strengths to achieve great deeds,
Leveraging what they can do to overcome what they cannot.

When the ruler gives them favorable timing,
The people repay him with wealth;
When the ruler treats them with **rites**,
The people repay him with death.

Thus, there are states in peril yet no secure ruler;
There are rulers in sorrow yet no contented ministers.

If **virtue/power** exceeds one’s station,
He is honored;
If **reward/luck** exceeds one’s **virtue/power**,
He is doomed.

**Virtue/power** is valued without limit,
**Righteousness** is sought without excess.
To hold **virtue/power** yet not be honored is to usurp one’s place;
To take **righteousness** yet not earn it is to steal wealth.

To be honored without **virtue/power** is doomed,
To take without **righteousness** is theft.

The **sage** finds contentment in poverty and joy in the **Dao/Way**,
Does not let desire harm life,
Does not let profit burden himself—
Thus he does not violate **righteousness** nor presumptuously seize what belongs to others.*

Without **virtue/power**, he is not honored;
Without ability, he is not appointed;
Without merit, he is not rewarded;
Without guilt, he is not punished.

In advancing men, he relies on **rites**;
In dismissing men, he relies on **righteousness**.

In the age of the petty man,
To advance him is like ascending to heaven;
To dismiss him is like descending into the abyss.
The **sage** in using men does not lightly advance nor easily dismiss;
The petty man fears advancement may not be lofty enough,
Regrets dismissal may not be deep enough.

To speak of the ancient is to criticize the present.
The present age is shallow and deceitful—
He loves those he wishes to live,
Hates those he wishes to die.

In judging horses, he errs by favoring the fat;
In selecting ministers, he errs by favoring the wealthy.
A plump pig fills the kitchen,
A gaunt one is heard in the temple.
Thus, the unworthy are appointed.

Though a horse be lean, if it is of fine breed,
It can still travel far;
Though a minister be poor, if he is loyal,
He can still accomplish great deeds.

The **noble man** discerns reality,
And does not trust slanderous words.
If a minister does not remonstrate when the ruler errs,
He is not a loyal servant;
If the ruler does not heed remonstrance,
He is not enlightened.

The one who does not remonstrate is called a **living corpse** (taking salary without duty),
The one who does not heed is a **tyrannical ruler**.

If the people sink in dissipation yet the ruler feels no concern,
He is not an **accomplished ruler**.
Thus, to uphold **rites** and die in hardship is the duty of a minister;
To endure cold and hunger is the kindness of a **benevolent father**.

If a ruler is thus, why fear the peril of the state?
If a minister is thus, why fear the lack of rank and reward?

chunks.original_text: 以大事小，谓之变人； 以小犯大，谓之逆天，前虽登天，后必入渊。 故乡里以齿，老穷不遗； 朝廷以爵，尊卑有差。 故长幼守其节，则祸患无由生。 夫崇贵者，为其近君也； 尊老者，谓其近亲也； 敬长者，谓其近兄也。 因君以崇贵，因亲而敬老，因礼而敬长也。 生而贵者骄，生而富者奢。 故富贵不以明道自鉴，而能无为非者寡矣。 贵不斯骄骄自至，富不辩奢奢自至。 处乎贵，不明道德，使不为非者，鲜矣。 学而不厌，所以治身也，教而不倦，所以治民也。 贤师良友，舍而为非者寡矣。 观学知#8道，承教无类，入芝兰之囿，必染芬芳之气也。 知贤之谓智，爱贤之谓仁，尊仁之谓义，敬贤之谓礼，乐贤之谓乐。 古之善为天下者，无为而无不为也，不生民事，故曰无为，因民所利，而无不为。 故为天下有容。 能得其容，无为而有功； 不得其容，动作必凶。 为天下有容者：豫兮其若冬涉大川； 犹兮其若畏四邻； 俨兮其若容； 涣兮其若冰之液； 敦兮其若朴； 混兮其若浊； 广兮其若谷。 此为天下容。 容，包容也。 道之容貌也，治天下者兢兢业业，不敢懈怠。 下文并释。 豫兮其若冬涉大川者，不敢行也； 犹兮其若畏邻者，恐四伤也； 俨兮其若容者，谦恭敬也； 涣兮其若冰之液者，不敢积藏也； 敦兮其若朴者，不敢廉成也； 混兮其若浊者，不敢明清也； 广兮其若谷者，不敢盛盈也。 进不敢行者，退不敢先也； 恐自伤者，守柔弱不敢矜也； 谦恭敬者，自卑下尊敬人也； 不敢积藏者，自损弊不敢坚也； 不敢廉成者，自亏缺不敢全也； 不敢清明者，处浊辱而不敢新鲜也； 不敢盛盈者，见不足而不敢自贤也。 夫道退故能先，守柔弱故能矜，自卑下故能高人，自损弊故实坚，自亏缺故盛全，处浊辱故新鲜，见不足故能贤。 道无为而无不为也。 此数者，道之反也。 处后则人先之，自损则人与之。 故天下戴之而不重，百姓乐推而不厌也。 通玄真经卷之十竟 ＃1 修达：瞿本作『条通』。 ＃2 聪：瞿本作『通』。 ＃3 下：原作『天下』，据瞿本删『天』。 ＃4 以：瞿本作『遂』。 ＃5 蒸：瞿本作『抄』。 ＃6 君：瞿本作『道』。 ＃7 妄取古：瞿本作『取安古』。 ＃8 知：原作『曰』，据瞿本改。 通玄真经卷之十一 默希子注
chunks.translated_text:
To serve the great with the small is called **perverting** (changing nature);
To offend the great with the small is called **defying the Dao/Way**—
Though one may ascend to heaven beforehand,
He will surely plunge into the abyss thereafter.

Thus, in the village, elders are honored by seniority,
And the aged and destitute are never abandoned;
In court, rank determines precedence,
With distinctions between high and low.

Therefore, when the old and young uphold their proper **rites**,
Calamities have no cause to arise.

The exalted are honored because they are near the ruler;
The aged are revered because they are near kin;
The elders are respected because they are near brothers.
Thus, one honors the noble through the ruler,
Respects the aged through kinship,
And reveres the elder through **rites**.

Those born noble grow arrogant,
Those born rich grow extravagant.
Thus, few who are rich and noble,
Without the **Dao/Way** to reflect upon,
Can avoid wrongdoing.

Nobility without humility invites arrogance,
Wealth without restraint invites extravagance.
To dwell in nobility yet fail to uphold **virtue/power**,
And not commit wrongdoing—how rare!

To study without surfeit is the way to cultivate oneself;
To teach without weariness is the way to govern the people.
With wise mentors and virtuous friends,
Few would abandon **rites** and still not err.

To observe learning is to know the **Dao/Way**,
To receive instruction is to embrace all without distinction—
Entering a garden of orchids and immortals,
One must surely inhale their fragrant **qi**.

To recognize the worthy is **wisdom**,
To love the worthy is **benevolence**,
To honor **benevolence** is **righteousness**,
To revere the worthy is **rites**,
To delight in the worthy is **music**.

The ancients who governed the world well
Did nothing yet accomplished all—
Not creating affairs for the people,
Thus called **non-action**,
Yet following what benefits the people,
Thus nothing was left undone.

Therefore, governing the world requires **tolerance**—
To obtain this **tolerance** is to achieve **non-action** yet fulfill all;
To fail in this **tolerance** is to act and invite disaster.

The **tolerance** of governing the world is thus:
**Cautious**, as if crossing a great river in winter;
**Wary**, as if fearing injury from all sides;
**Dignified**, as if maintaining **rites**;
**Dissolved**, as if ice melting;
**Sincere**, as if uncarved wood;
**Mingled**, as if turbid water;
**Vast**, as if a valley.

This is the **tolerance** of governing the world.
**Tolerance** means encompassing all.

The **Dao/Way**’s appearance is thus:
The ruler governs with diligence, never slacking.

---
**Explanations of the above:**

**Cautious**, as if crossing a great river in winter—
Not daring to act rashly;

**Wary**, as if fearing injury from all sides—
Fearful of harm on every front;

**Dignified**, as if maintaining **rites**—
Humility, respect, and deference;

**Dissolved**, as if ice melting—
Not daring to hoard;

**Sincere**, as if uncarved wood—
Not daring to be artificially perfected;

**Mingled**, as if turbid water—
Not daring to seek clarity alone;

**Vast**, as if a valley—
Not daring to be full to overflowing.

To advance without daring to act,
To retreat without daring to lead—
To fear self-harm,
To cling to gentleness and not presume strength—
To humble oneself and honor others—
To diminish oneself and thus truly endure—
To be deficient and thus remain whole—
To endure filth and humiliation yet remain fresh—
To see insufficiency and thus not claim superiority.

The **Dao/Way** retreats yet leads,
Clings to weakness yet prevails,
Humbles itself yet rises above others,
Diminishes itself yet stands firm,
Lacks yet remains complete,
Endures filth yet remains pure,
Sees insufficiency yet is worthy.

The **Dao/Way** does nothing yet accomplishes all.

These are the inversions of the **Dao/Way**.
To place oneself last is to be first for others,
To diminish oneself is to gain from others.

Thus, the world reveres it without burden,
And the people willingly follow without exhaustion.

chunks.original_text: 上义 老子曰：凡学者，能明於天人之分，通於治乱之本，澄心清意以存之，见其终始，反於虚无，可谓达矣。 唯夫体清，明反虚静，故能明天人之分，究纷始之际。 治之本，仁义也； 其末，法度也。 人之所生者，本也； 其所不生者，末也。 本末一体也，其两爱之性也。 先本后末，谓之君子； 先末后本，谓之小人。 人之生也，精神为本，形体为末。 故太上养神，治其情性； 末世养形，恣其嗜欲。 治性则神清，纵欲则身害。 夫神清体和，本末相济，乃全身保神，不亏其真，凡修摄有方，禀受不一，故有君子小人之异。 法之生也，以辅义，重法弃义，是贵其冠履，而忘其首足也。 治国者先治於仁义，然后法令以齐之。 重法令，遗仁义，是遗首足而贵冠履也。 仁义者，广崇也。 不益其厚而张其广者，毁； 不广其基而增其高者，覆。 故不大其栋，不能任重，任重莫若楝，任国莫若德。 人主之有民，犹城中之有基，木之有根。 根深即本固，基厚即上安。 根基犹道德也。 夫根深基广而见毁拔者，未之有也，道高德盛而万姓不崇戴者，未之闻也。 故事不本於道德者，不可以为经； 言不合於先王者，不可以为道。 夫事不师。 古，不遵道，不可为国法。 便说棳取一行一功之术，非天下通道也。 恢怪谲诡之术，非天下之大道。 老子曰：治人之道，其犹造父之御驷马也。 周穆王时御马。 齐辑音集。 之乎辔衔，正度之乎胸膺，内得於中心，外合乎马志，故能取道致远，气力有余，进退还曲，莫不如意，诚得其术也。 今夫权势者，人主之车舆也； 大臣者，人主之驷马也。 身不可离车舆之安，手不可失驷马之心。 故驷马不调，造父不能以取道，君臣不和，圣人不能以为治。 执道以御之中才可尽； 明分以示之，奸邪可止。 物至而观其变，事来而应其化。 近者不乱，即远者治矣。 不用适然之教，而得自然之道，万举而不失矣。 有造父之善御，不忧车马之奔逸； 有圣人之至治，不忧黔首之危亡。 老子曰：凡为道者，塞邪隧＃1，防未然。 不贵其自是也，贵其不得为非也。 故曰：勿使可欲，无日不求； 勿使可夺，无日不争。 如此即人欲释而公道行矣。 有余者，止於度； 不足者，逮於用，故天下可一人也。 夫释职事而听非誉，弃功劳而用朋党，即奇伎天长，守职不进； 民俗乱於国，功臣争於朝。 故有道以御人，无道则制於人矣。 舜为匹夫而天下共戴者，其道存也，故能制於人； 纣为天子，而四海离心者，其道亡也，则为人所制。 老子曰：治国有常，而利民为本； 政教有道，而令行为古。 苟利於民，不必法古； 苟周於事，不必循俗。 故圣人法与时变，礼与俗化。 衣服器械，各便其用； 法度制令，各因其宜。 故变古未可非，而循俗未足多也。 夫治道所贵，适时而已。 不在数变为务也。 诵先王之书，不若闻其言； 闻其言，不若得其所以言。 得其所以言者，言不能言也。 故道可道，非常道也； 名可名，非常名也。 执言为道，即言而非道也，持石为玉，即石而非玉也。 故圣人所由曰道，犹金石也，一调不可更； 音律以定，不可易也。 事犹琴瑟也，曲终改调。 曲节既殊，故宜变易。 法制礼乐者，治之具也，非所以为治也。 故曲士不可与论至道者，讯寤於俗而束於教也。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao/Way** of clarity—Laozi says:

All who study the **Dao/Way**,
If they can discern the distinction between Heaven and humanity,
And grasp the root of order and chaos,
If they purify the heart and clarify the mind to preserve it,
And observe its beginning and end,
Returning to the emptiness and stillness—
Then they may be said to have attained it.

Only those who embody purity,
And clearly return to emptiness and tranquility,
Can truly discern the distinction between Heaven and humanity,
And fathom the origins of all confusion.

The root of governance is **virtue/power** and righteousness;
Its branches are laws and statutes.
What gives birth to humanity is the root;
What does not is the branch.
Root and branch are one in essence,
Yet their dual nature is love and desire.

Prioritizing root over branch—this is the **君子** (junzi/noble one);
Prioritizing branch over root—this is the **小人** (xiao ren/commoner).

In the birth of humanity,
Spirit is the root,
Form is the branch.
Thus, in the **太上** (Great Sage) era, nurturing of spirit prevails,
And emotions and inclinations are regulated;
In the **末世** (Later Age), form is cherished,
And appetites and desires run wild.
Regulating desire clarifies the spirit,
Indulging desire harms the body.

When the spirit is clear and the body harmonious,
Root and branch mutually support,
Then one preserves the whole body and safeguards the spirit,
Without diminishing its true essence.
All methods of cultivation and discipline vary,
And inherent capacities differ—
Thus arise the distinctions between noble and common.

When laws arise,
They serve to aid **virtue/power** and righteousness;
If laws are exalted and **virtue/power** abandoned,
This is like valuing one’s cap and shoes
While neglecting one’s head and feet.

In governing a state,
One must first establish **virtue/power** and righteousness,
Then laws and decrees to bring order.
If laws and decrees are emphasized,
And **virtue/power** and righteousness neglected,
This is like neglecting one’s head and feet
While valuing one’s cap and shoes.

**Virtue/power** and righteousness are broad and profound.
To increase their height without broadening their foundation—this is ruin;
To extend their reach without deepening their root—this is destruction.

Thus, without great beams,
One cannot bear heavy burdens;
To bear burdens, none surpass **楝** (yuán, a strong tree);
To govern a state, none surpass **德** (virtue).

The ruler’s people are like the foundation of a city,
Or the roots of a tree.
Deep roots mean a firm foundation,
A thick base means a secure height.
Foundation and roots are like **德** (virtue) and the **Dao/Way**.

When a foundation is deep and broad,
Yet it is destroyed—this has never occurred.
When the **Dao/Way** is high and **德** (virtue) flourishes,
Yet the people do not revere it—this has never been heard.

Thus, what is not rooted in **德** (virtue) and the **Dao/Way**
Cannot be called a true principle;
What does not align with the ancient kings
Cannot be called the **Dao/Way**.

If one does not learn from antiquity,
And does not follow the **Dao/Way**,
Then it cannot be the law of the state.
To merely recite the methods of one deed or one merit,
This is not the universal **Dao/Way**.
To employ bizarre and deceptive techniques,
This is not the great **Dao/Way** of the world.

Laozi says:
The **Dao/Way** of governing people
Is like **造父** (Zào Fǔ, a legendary charioteer) guiding his four horses.
In the time of King **周穆王** (Zhōu Mù Wáng, King Mu of Zhou),
Zào Fǔ drove his horses.
With reins and bit in hand,
He aligned their movements with his own chest,
Gained their trust from within,
And harmonized their wills from without.
Thus he could take the **Dao/Way** and travel far,
With energy and strength to spare.
Advancing or retreating, turning or bending—
All went as he intended.
Truly, he mastered the technique!

Now, **权势** (authority and influence) are the ruler’s carriage;
Great ministers are the ruler’s four horses.
The body cannot abandon the carriage’s stability,
The hands cannot lose the horses’ hearts.
Thus, if the four horses are not attuned,
Zào Fǔ cannot guide them along the **Dao/Way**;
If ruler and ministers are not in harmony,
Even the **圣人** (sage) cannot govern with them.

To grasp the **Dao/Way** and guide with it—
Even mediocre talent can achieve this;
To clearly distinguish and demonstrate—
Even the wicked can be restrained.
Things come to completion while observing their changes,
Affairs unfold while responding to their transformations.
If the near are not disordered,
Then the far will naturally be governed.
Without employing contrived teachings,
Yet attaining the natural **Dao/Way**,
All actions will be without error.

With **造父**’s skill in guiding,
One need not fear the horses’ wild galloping;
With the **圣人**’s supreme governance,
One need not fear the people’s peril and ruin.

Laozi says:
All who practice the **Dao/Way**,
Must block the paths of evil and unseen forces,
And prevent what has not yet occurred.
They value not their own self-righteousness,
But rather their inability to act wrongly.
Thus it is said:
Do not allow what is desired to exist,
Or there will be no day without strife;
Do not allow what is to be taken to exist,
Or there will be no day without contention.
Thus, when desires are released,
The public **Dao/Way** prevails.

Those in excess are stopped by measure;
Those in deficiency are urged by use.
Thus, the world can be governed by one.

If one abandons official duties
And listens to praise and blame,
If one discards merit and labor
And relies on factions and cliques,
Then even with extraordinary talents,
One will not advance in office;
While the people’s customs decay in the state,
And ministers vie for power in court.

Thus, with the **Dao/Way** to guide people,
One is not guided by people;
Without the **Dao/Way**, one is constrained by people.
**舜** (Shùn, a virtuous ruler) as a commoner
Was revered by all under Heaven—
Because his **Dao/Way** endured,
And thus he could guide others.
**纣** (Zhòu, the tyrannical last king of Xia) as a ruler
Lost the loyalty of the four seas—
Because his **Dao/Way** perished,
And thus he was constrained by others.

Laozi says:
In governing a state, there are constants,
Yet benefiting the people is the root;
In governance and teaching, there is a **Dao/Way**,
Yet decrees and conduct follow antiquity.
If it benefits the people,
It need not strictly adhere to the old ways;
If it harmonizes with affairs,
It need not blindly follow custom.

Thus, the **圣人** adapts laws to the times,
And rituals to the customs.
Clothing and tools,
Each serve their purpose;
Laws and decrees,
Each suit their needs.
Thus, changing antiquity is not wrong,
Nor is following custom always commendable.

What is valued in governance
Is only fitting the times.
It is not a matter of frequent alteration.

Reading the books of ancient kings,
Is not as good as hearing their words;
Hearing their words,
Is not as good as understanding their intent.
To grasp their intent—
Their words cannot fully express it.

Thus, the **Dao/Way** that can be spoken of
Is not the constant **Dao/Way**;
The name that can be named
Is not the constant name.
To hold words as the **Dao/Way**,
Is to hold words while not possessing the **Dao/Way**;
To cling to stone as jade,
Is to cling to stone while not possessing jade.

Thus, the **Dao/Way** spoken of by the **圣人**
Is like metal and stone—
Once refined, it cannot be altered.
The principles of sound and rhythm
Are fixed and cannot be changed.
Governance is like the **琴瑟** (qin se, musical instruments);
When the melody ends, the tuning shifts.
Since the notes differ,
Thus it is fitting to change and adapt.
Laws, statutes, rituals, and music
Are the tools of governance,
Not the governance itself.

Thus, those who are skilled in technique
Cannot be consulted on the ultimate **Dao/Way**,
For they are bound by doctrine and awaken only to the common.
